However, White House lawyers are said to have vetoed the kidnapping plan. Despite this, other operations against WikiLeaks reportedly went forward, including efforts to infiltrate the organization and compromise its sources.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and over 20 other rights groups have seized on the revelations, urging Attorney General Merrick Garland to drop the ongoing prosecution of Assange. In a joint letter, they argued that the CIA's alleged misconduct underscores the broader implications of Assange's case for press freedom.

Assange's legal team intends to use the CIA's alleged actions as part of their argument against his extradition from the United Kingdom to the United States, where he faces charges under the Espionage Act for publishing classified military and diplomatic documents.

Pompeo, now a U.S. senator, acknowledged some accuracy in the Yahoo News report but denied any plans to assassinate Assange. "We didn't assassinate Julian Assange," Pompeo told Fox News. "We were trying to figure out lawful ways to get him held accountable."

The revelations have sparked widespread outrage and demands for transparency and accountability. Critics argue that the CIA's alleged actions threaten the First Amendment rights of journalists and the public's right to know. The House Intelligence Committee's investigation aims to shed light on these covert operations and ensure that proper oversight mechanisms are in place to prevent overreach in the future.

As the inquiry unfolds, attention turns to the Biden administration and its stance on Assange's prosecution. The outcome could have far-reaching consequences for the balance between national security and press freedom in the digital age.

Facebook Whistleblower Frances Haugen Exposes Company's Harmful Algorithms and Prioritization of Profit

Frances Haugen, a 37-year-old former Facebook employee, has come forward as the whistleblower who exposed the social media giant's internal documents to Congress, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and The Wall Street Journal. Haugen, who worked as a product manager on the civic misinformation team, applied for federal whistleblower protection before publicly revealing her identity, criticizing the company's algorithms and policies.

In a recent interview, Haugen expressed her concerns, stating, "The thing I saw at Facebook over and over again was there were conflicts of interest between what was good for the public and what was good for Facebook. And Facebook, over and over again, chose to optimize for its own interests, like making more money."

Haugen's revelations have shed light on how Facebook's algorithms can harm teenagers' mental health, with a particular emphasis on the negative impact of Instagram. She claims the platform amplifies content that can be detrimental to young users, leading Facebook to temporarily halt the development of Instagram Kids. "Facebook's products harm children, stoke division, and weaken our democracy," Haugen said.

The whistleblower accused Facebook of prioritizing profit over safety, alleging that the company's internal actions contradicted its public statements on combating misinformation and violent extremism. Haugen argued that Facebook promotes divisive and harmful content because it increases engagement, even if it contributes to societal harm. "The version of Facebook that exists today is tearing our societies apart and causing real harm to people," she said.

While Haugen has been vocal in her criticism, she also expressed empathy towards Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, acknowledging that he may not be fully aware of the extent of the problems within the company. "I don't think Mark is a bad person. I think when you have a system that is optimized for maximizing profits above all else, it leads to really bad outcomes," she said.

Taliban Blames U.S. for Kabul Airport Attack, Vows to Protect Foreign Nationals and Women's Rights

In the aftermath of the devastating August 27 attack on Kabul's Hamid Karzai International Airport, which claimed the lives of over 170 Afghans and 13 U.S. service members, the Taliban has pointed fingers at the United States, alleging that the chaos surrounding the evacuation was the root cause of the tragedy. In an attempt to address concerns about women's rights under the new regime, the Taliban claims it will support equal opportunities for women to study and work, as long as they adhere to Islamic law. Karimi said, "Women have the right to education and work, but they must wear hijabs and follow the Islamic dress code to avoid provoking men."

President Biden Leads Global COVID-19 Summit, Pledges Additional 500 Million Vaccine Doses and Strengthened Global Health Security Efforts

Washington, D.C. – Today, President Joe Biden co-hosted the Global COVID-19 Summit alongside the United Nations (UN) General Assembly, convening world leaders, private sector partners, and global health organizations to accelerate efforts in ending the COVID-19 pandemic and enhancing global health security. The summit aimed to achieve four main objectives: vaccinating the world, saving lives now, building back better, and holding the international community accountable through measurable targets.

In his remarks, President Biden announced that the United States will donate an additional 500 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine to low and lower-middle-income countries. This commitment brings the total number of vaccine doses pledged by the U.S. to over 1.1 billion, underscoring the country's leadership in the global fight against the pandemic.

To further strengthen global vaccine readiness and delivery, the President shared that the United States plans to allocate additional funding through the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). These investments will support crucial aspects of the vaccine distribution process, including cold chain infrastructure, logistics, and monitoring systems.

The U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) has committed over $383 million in political risk insurance to facilitate the swift and secure shipment of vaccines to countries in need. This commitment underscores the Biden Administration's commitment to removing barriers to vaccine access and ensuring equitable distribution worldwide.

In an effort to boost vaccine production capacity in developing countries, the U.S. has also invested in vaccine manufacturing facilities in Africa and India. These investments will help expand global and regional production, reducing dependence on a limited number of suppliers and fostering self-sufficiency.

President Biden reiterated the United States' support for a temporary waiver of intellectual property protections under the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) for COVID-19 vaccines. This measure aims to promote knowledge sharing and enable more manufacturers to produce vaccines, thereby increasing global supply.

In addition to vaccine distribution efforts, USAID and the CDC will provide nearly $1.4 billion to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 and strengthen health systems worldwide. These funds will help address critical needs such as testing, treatment, and the prevention of further transmission.

The Global COVID-19 Summit serves as a call to action for global cooperation and underscores the urgency in addressing the ongoing pandemic. It also highlights the importance of preparing for future health crises by investing in resilient health systems, strengthening public health institutions, and fostering international collaboration.

In his closing remarks, President Biden emphasized the shared responsibility of the global community in ending the pandemic and rebuilding a healthier, safer world. "We must act together, as a global community, to save lives, stem the tide of this pandemic, and build back better than ever before," he said.

The summit marks a significant step forward in the global response to COVID-19, demonstrating the United States' unwavering commitment to ending the pandemic and fostering a more equitable and prepared world.

Fourth Federal Stimulus Check Unlikely as States Step Up with Relief Efforts

Despite a petition for recurring $2,000 stimulus payments amassing over 2.9 million signatures, a fourth round of federal stimulus checks seems increasingly unlikely. Parents have the option to receive these funds in monthly installments or as a lump sum during tax season.

The third round of stimulus payments, worth up to $1,400 per eligible individual, is still being distributed, with 'plus-up' payments being sent to those who recently became eligible, such as new dependents added in 2021. "We're committed to making sure that those who are eligible receive the full amount they're entitled to," Psaki noted.

FDA and CDC Lift Recommended Pause on Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 Vaccine After Safety Review

Washington, D.C. — The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have announced the lifting of the recommended pause on the use of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) COVID-19 vaccine in the United States. This decision follows a thorough safety review and extensive consultations with medical and scientific experts.

The pause was initially recommended on April 13th after six reports of a rare and severe type of blood clot, known as thrombosis-thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS), emerged among individuals who had received the vaccine. Since then, the FDA and CDC have carefully assessed the risks and benefits associated with the vaccine.

"After a thorough review of the available data, medical and scientific teams at the FDA and CDC have determined that the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine's known and potential benefits outweigh its known and potential risks for individuals 18 years of age and older," said Janet Woodcock, M.D., Acting FDA Commissioner.

Dr. Woodcock emphasized the agency's commitment to vaccine safety, stating, "The FDA's top priority is ensuring the safety of vaccines for the American people. Our decision to resume use of the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine is based on a comprehensive analysis of the available data and our confidence in the vaccine's overall safety profile."

During the pause, revised fact sheets for healthcare providers and vaccine recipients were developed to include information about the risk of TTS. The CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) also reviewed the latest data on TTS, contributing to the decision to lift the pause.

According to CDC Director Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, the pause demonstrated the effectiveness of the nation's vaccine safety systems. "This pause highlights just how seriously we take vaccine safety," Dr. Walensky said. "I encourage anyone with questions about the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine to speak with their healthcare provider."

As of the time of the decision, a total of 15 cases of TTS have been reported to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS), all in women aged between 18 and 59 years. Data suggest that the chance of developing TTS after receiving the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine remains very low.

The FDA and CDC continue to monitor the safety of all COVID-19 vaccines authorized for emergency use in the United States. Healthcare providers are advised to remain vigilant for symptoms of TTS and to report any potential cases to VAERS.

The resumption of the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine bolsters the nation's vaccination efforts, offering an additional tool to combat the ongoing pandemic. The one-dose vaccine has been shown to be highly effective in preventing severe COVID-19, hospitalization, and death.

Both agencies reiterate their commitment to transparency and public trust in the vaccination process. The collaboration between the FDA, CDC, and healthcare providers ensures that the American public can have confidence in the safety and efficacy of COVID-19 vaccines.

FDA Expands Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Booster Eligibility to 16- and 17-Year-Olds

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has announced an expansion of the eligibility for the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 booster dose to include 16- and 17-year-olds. This authorization comes after a thorough review of safety and effectiveness data, further reinforcing the agency's commitment to combatting the ongoing pandemic.

Acting FDA Commissioner Janet Woodcock, M.D., emphasized the significance of this decision, stating, "As we move forward in our fight against COVID-19, we continue to prioritize the health and safety of all Americans, including our younger population. Today's action allows for 16- and 17-year-olds to receive a booster dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at least six months after their primary series, providing added protection against the virus."

This expansion follows the FDA's authorization on November 19, which allowed booster doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for individuals 18 years and older. It is important to note that the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine, also known as Comirnaty, is the only vaccine authorized for use in the 16- and 17-year-old age group.

Dr. Peter Marks, M.D., Ph.D., the director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, explained the rationale behind the decision, saying, "We have observed waning immunity over time following the primary vaccination series, particularly in certain populations. The available data support the benefits of a single booster dose in this age group, helping to maintain a high level of protection against the virus."

The FDA's analysis has shown that a booster dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine elicits a robust immune response in both adults and youth, supporting its effectiveness in preventing severe COVID-19, hospitalization, and death. In making this decision, the agency carefully assessed the potential risks, including myocarditis and pericarditis, which have been reported in a small number of adolescents and young adults following vaccination.

Dr. Woodcock addressed these concerns, stating, "We have determined that the known and potential benefits of a booster dose in 16- and 17-year-olds outweigh the known and potential risks, including the risk of myocarditis. We will continue to closely monitor the safety of the vaccine, and Pfizer is conducting studies to better understand the risk of myocarditis and pericarditis."

The FDA did not convene the Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee for this decision, as it was based on a comprehensive review of existing data and information. The agency collaborated with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to evaluate the need for boosters in this age group, and the CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) is expected to meet soon to discuss recommendations for the use of the booster dose in 16- and 17-year-olds.

NEW YORK (AP) – CNN host Chris Cuomo has announced that he will not be covering the sexual harassment allegations against his brother, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, acknowledging the inherent conflict of interest in such a situation. Chris Cuomo made the statement at the beginning of his prime time show, underscoring CNN's commitment to reporting on the story impartially.

"The rule here is simple: I usually don't talk about family on this show, and I normally don't cover stories involving my brother," Chris Cuomo said. "CNN has a rule that I cannot do it, and I have respected that."

The Cuomo brothers gained attention last year for their joint appearances on CNN during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, engaging in lighthearted banter that raised ethical concerns about the network's impartiality. CNN temporarily suspended its rule preventing Chris from covering stories about Andrew during that time.

However, with three women now accusing the governor of sexual harassment, the situation has taken a serious turn, leading to calls for an independent investigation. Critics, including journalism experts, argue that CNN's earlier decision to allow the Cuomo brothers to interact on air was a violation of journalistic ethics.

Steven Thrasher, a journalism professor at Northwestern University, commented, "When you're a journalist, your job is to cover the news, not be in it. CNN's decision to let Chris Cuomo cover his brother during the pandemic was a mistake that has now come back to haunt them."

Scott Stroud, ethics director at the Center for Media Engagement at the University of Texas at Austin, echoed these concerns, saying, "The appearance of impropriety is just as damaging as actual impropriety in journalism. CNN should have maintained a clear separation between Chris and Andrew from the beginning."

Fox News Channel meteorologist Janice Dean, who has been a vocal critic of Governor Cuomo's nursing home policies, dismissed Chris Cuomo's statement as insufficient. "Actions speak louder than words," Dean said. "The damage has already been done, and the public's trust in CNN has been eroded."

Jacqueline Jones, a professor at Morgan State University's School of Global Journalism and Communication, believes the situation highlights the challenges faced by news organizations in maintaining credibility.

"This case underscores the importance of maintaining strict ethical boundaries, particularly in an era when the lines between news, punditry, and entertainment are increasingly blurred," Jones said.

COVID-19 Vaccines Proven Safe and Effective in Major Real-World Study

Recent clinical trials have consistently demonstrated the efficacy and safety of COVID-19 vaccines, and a groundbreaking new study published in The New England Journal of Medicine adds further weight to these findings. Conducted by an international team of researchers from the Clalit Research Institute in Israel, Harvard Medical School, and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, the study analyzed data from nearly 2 million individuals, providing a comprehensive real-world assessment of the Pfizer/BioNTech BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine.

Dr. Ben Reis, an assistant professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School and director of the predictive medicine group at Boston Children's Hospital's Computational Health Informatics Program, emphasized the significance of the study in addressing vaccine hesitancy. "This study is crucial in providing detailed safety information that can help individuals make informed decisions about vaccination," he said. "It confirms what we've seen in clinical trials and adds valuable context to the conversation."

The research identified myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart muscle, as a rare side effect associated with the vaccine, occurring at a rate of 2.7 excess cases per 100,000 vaccinated people. However, Ran Balicer, director of the Clalit Research Institute and chief innovation officer for Clalit, the largest healthcare provider in Israel, stressed that the benefits of vaccination far outweigh the risks. "The study underscores the safety profile of mRNA vaccines," Balicer stated. "The risks of myocarditis and other serious conditions are significantly higher in unvaccinated individuals who contract SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing COVID-19."

In addition to myocarditis, the study also examined 25 other potential adverse events in vaccinated versus unvaccinated individuals. While some events, such as lymph node swelling, appendicitis, and reactivation of herpes zoster, were moderately associated with vaccination, they were found to be rare occurrences. These findings complement the results from the Pfizer/BioNTech phase 3 randomized clinical trial, further solidifying the safety and efficacy profile of the vaccine.

The study's large sample size and real-world setting make it a valuable contribution to the global understanding of COVID-19 vaccine safety. Dr. Reis highlighted the importance of such research, stating, "Real-world data is critical in understanding how vaccines perform in diverse populations and under different circumstances. This study provides reassurance to the public and healthcare professionals alike."

Ran Balicer, who also serves as chairman of Israel's National Expert Advisory Team on COVID-19 response, underlined the need for continued vaccination efforts. "The data is clear: the risks of natural coronavirus morbidity are far greater than the potential side effects of the vaccine," he said. "This study reinforces the need for widespread vaccination to protect individuals and communities from the severe consequences of COVID-19."

World's Largest Container Vessel, EVER ACE, Successfully Navigates Suez Canal on Maiden Voyage

In a remarkable feat of maritime engineering, the world's largest container ship, the EVER ACE, completed its maiden voyage through the Suez Canal on its way to Europe. Operated by Taiwan-based Evergreen Marine Corporation, the colossal vessel was built by South Korea's Samsung Heavy Industries and has set a new benchmark in the shipping industry.

EVER ACE boasts an impressive carrying capacity of 23,992 TEU (twenty-foot equivalent units), surpassing the previous record holder, the HMM Algeciras. The ship's dimensions are equally staggering, measuring 400 meters in length, 61.53 meters in width, and weighing around 235,000 tons. This behemoth is the first in a series of 12 container ships that Evergreen has ordered, reflecting the company's commitment to modernizing and expanding its fleet.

The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) played a crucial role in ensuring the safe passage of the mammoth vessel, providing expert navigation support. The successful transit not only underscores the canal's capability to accommodate the world's largest container ships but also highlights the SCA's efforts to enhance the canal's efficiency and accommodate growing maritime traffic.

Setting sail from the Port of Taipei, Taiwan, the EVER ACE is now en route to Rotterdam, Netherlands, where it is scheduled to arrive on September 4. Its journey symbolizes the resilience and adaptability of global shipping routes, especially in the wake of the high-profile grounding of Evergreen's Ever Given in March, which led to a six-day blockage of the canal and significant disruptions to global trade.

The successful maiden voyage of the EVER ACE is a testament to the advancements in shipbuilding technology and the continued importance of the Suez Canal as a vital link in global trade. As the shipping industry continues to evolve, vessels like the EVER ACE will play a key role in meeting the increasing demand for efficient and sustainable transportation of goods across the world.

The Ever Given Saga: Navigating the Complexities of General Average in a High-Stakes Insurance Dispute

The unprecedented grounding of the Ever Given container ship in the Suez Canal earlier this year has not only caused a massive disruption in global trade but has also unleashed a intricate legal and insurance battle. The principle of general average, a centuries-old maritime law, is at the heart of this dispute, implicating vessel owners, cargo interests, and shippers alike.

According to Joe Klobus, Claims and Insurance Manager at OEC Group, "General average is a fundamental concept in maritime law that ensures the equitable sharing of loss when a voluntary sacrifice is made for the common safety of all parties involved in a sea voyage." This principle is governed by the York Antwerp Rules, which outline the circumstances under which it can be invoked.

In the case of the Ever Given, the vessel's owners, not the operator Evergreen Line, have invoked general average. This means that all parties with a stake in the cargo, including shippers, will be required to contribute to the costs associated with the vessel's refloating, salvage, and any other expenses incurred during the incident.

Klobus explains, "General average can be called upon in various situations, such as when a vessel needs to be salvaged or seeks refuge. It's not just limited to vessel fires or containers going overboard, as commonly perceived."

The Egyptian authorities have demanded a staggering $900 million in compensation, which includes a $300 million salvage bonus and another $300 million for the loss of reputation to the Suez Canal Authority. This figure underscores the gravity of the financial implications for all parties involved.

However, shippers whose vessels were delayed due to the Ever Given's grounding should not expect to declare general average, as delays do not fall within the parameters set by the York Antwerp Rules. As Klobus points out, "For a general average claim to be valid, there needs to be a voluntary sacrifice or expenditure made for the common safety. A delay, unfortunately, does not meet this criteria."

This incident highlights the growing prevalence of general average declarations, particularly in light of the increasing number of incidents involving containers falling overboard. As Klobus notes, "With more frequent incidents, it's crucial for shippers to understand the implications of general average when entering into contracts."

The potential impact on consumer prices cannot be overlooked. The costs associated with the Ever Given and similar incidents could ultimately be passed on to consumers as part of the landed costs, affecting the overall market. Klobus warns, "Shippers need to be aware that these charges can have a ripple effect on the supply chain, potentially driving up the cost of goods for end-users."

In conclusion, the Ever Given's grounding in the Suez Canal has shed light on the complexities of maritime law and the importance of understanding the principle of general average. As global trade continues to evolve, it is imperative for all stakeholders to be well-versed in these legal intricacies to mitigate potential financial risks and navigate the ever-changing landscape of the shipping industry.

Rittenhouse's decision to testify was seen as a risky move, but Meyn believes it ultimately worked in the defense's favor. WHO Designates New SARS-CoV-2 Variant B.1.1.529 as a Variant of Concern, Named Omicron

Geneva, Switzerland - The World Health Organization (WHO) Technical Advisory Group on SARS-CoV-2 Virus Evolution (TAG-VE) met on 26 November 2021 to evaluate the recently identified B.1.1.529 variant of the virus responsible for COVID-19. This variant was first reported to the WHO by South Africa on 24 November, with the earliest known infection dating back to 9 November 2021.

The B.1.1.529 variant, now designated as a Variant of Concern (VOC) and named Omicron, has drawn global attention due to its significant number of mutations. Preliminary evidence indicates that this variant may pose an increased risk of reinfection compared to other circulating variants.

South Africa has witnessed a rapid rise in Omicron cases across most of its provinces, highlighting the potential for increased transmissibility. However, current SARS-CoV-2 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) diagnostic tests remain effective in detecting the Omicron variant. A notable feature is the S gene target failure in one PCR test, which can serve as an indicator of this specific variant.

Based on the available evidence, the TAG-VE recommended the classification of B.1.1.529 as a VOC. The WHO has promptly communicated this decision to its member states and will continue to provide updates as new information becomes available.

In response to the emergence of Omicron, the WHO is urging countries to enhance their surveillance and sequencing efforts to identify and report cases associated with this VOC. Public health measures, such as mask-wearing, physical distancing, hand hygiene, and ventilation, remain critical in controlling the spread of the virus. Vaccination against COVID-19 is also essential, as it continues to provide protection against severe disease and death.

The WHO defines a Variant of Interest (VOI) as a SARS-CoV-2 variant with specific genetic changes that are suspected to affect transmissibility, disease severity, immunity, or diagnostic or therapeutic tools. A Variant of Concern (VOC), like Omicron, is a VOI that has been demonstrated to have increased transmissibility, more severe disease, decreased effectiveness of treatments or vaccines, or difficulty in detection.

Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, the WHO's COVID-19 Technical Lead, emphasized the importance of global collaboration in monitoring and responding to new variants. "We must work together to understand the potential implications of this variant and ensure that all countries have access to the tools and resources needed to detect, sequence, and respond effectively," she stated.

As the world continues to grapple with the ongoing pandemic, the WHO's classification of Omicron as a VOC underscores the need for continued vigilance, research, and global cooperation in the fight against COVID-19.

WHO Approves Two AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 Vaccine Variants for Emergency Use

The World Health Organization (WHO) has granted Emergency Use Listing (EUL) to two versions of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine, produced by AstraZeneca-SKBio in the Republic of Korea and the Serum Institute of India. This decision marks a significant milestone in the global fight against the pandemic, as it paves the way for faster regulatory approval in countries and ensures a steady supply through the COVAX Facility.

Dr. Mariângela Simão, WHO Assistant-Director General for Access to Medicines and Health Products, underscored the importance of equitable vaccine distribution, stating, "The world desperately needs multiple COVID-19 vaccines to address the huge access disparities across the globe. Today's decision by the WHO adds another vaccine to the global effort to control the pandemic and brings us closer to protecting people everywhere."

Emergency Use Listing is a crucial step for vaccines to be distributed through the COVAX Facility, a global initiative aimed at ensuring equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines for all countries, regardless of their economic status. This listing allows countries to expedite their own regulatory approval processes, speeding up the vaccine rollout.

The EUL process requires vaccine developers to submit comprehensive data for a swift assessment by the WHO. In the case of the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines, this process took less than four weeks, including the evaluation of various clinical trial data and inspections of manufacturing sites.

The Strategic Advisory Group of Experts (SAGE) on Immunization has recommended the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine, known as ChAdOx1-S, for use in individuals aged 18 and above. With an efficacy rate of 63.09%, this vaccine is particularly suitable for low- and middle-income countries due to its easier storage and transportation requirements compared to some other vaccines.

Dr. Simão emphasized the significance of the EUL procedure, highlighting its role in ensuring safety, efficacy, and quality of health products during emergencies. El Paso's Winter Storm Resilience: A Lesson in Preparedness and Infrastructure

While millions of Texans grappled with power outages, frozen pipes, and scarce resources, El Paso resident Robert Gomez found local stores fully stocked and utilities functioning smoothly. "It was like a different world," Gomez said. "I couldn't believe the contrast between here and what I was seeing on the news from other cities."

El Paso's ability to weather the storm can be attributed to its preparations following a severe winter storm in 2011, as well as its connection to the Western Interconnection power grid. Steve Buraczyk, Senior Vice President of Operations at El Paso Electric, explained, "After the 2011 storm, we invested millions in winterizing our facilities, including the construction of the Montana Power Station, which has dual-fuel capability. This allowed us to maintain service even when natural gas supplies were impacted."

Unlike the majority of Texas, which falls under the jurisdiction of the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT), El Paso Electric is part of the Western Interconnection. ERCOT, managing about 90% of the state's electric load, was unable to draw power from other states during the storm, exacerbating the crisis. Ramanan Krishnamoorti, Chief Energy Officer at the University of Houston, pointed out, "ERCOT's isolation from other grids was a major factor in the outages. El Paso's connection to the Western Interconnection provided a crucial redundancy."

However, the lack of mandatory winterization requirements for Texas power companies played a significant role in the crisis. Many, including ERCOT, issued voluntary guidelines after the 2011 outages, but these were largely ignored. Carey King, Assistant Director at the University of Texas's Energy Institute, noted, "Voluntary measures aren't enough. If companies aren't incentivized or required to prepare for extreme weather, they often won't."

El Paso Electric's participation in the Western Interconnection creates an incentive for winterization, as it allows the company to sell excess energy to neighboring states. This economic benefit, combined with the lessons learned from past storms, has made El Paso more resilient. However, the widespread suffering in Texas underscores the need for systemic changes in policy and planning.

Chauvin, who is white, is already facing state murder and manslaughter charges in connection with Floyd's death, with his trial set to commence on March 8.

The federal investigation, which sources say involves other officers as witnesses, adds another layer to the legal proceedings against Chauvin. Three other former officers, Tou Thao, J. Alexander Kueng, and Thomas Lane, are charged with aiding and abetting Chauvin and are scheduled to stand trial in August.

Floyd's death on May 25, captured on bystander video, showed Chauvin with his knee on Floyd's neck as the 46-year-old Black man cried out, "I can't breathe." The incident led to months of demonstrations against racial injustice and police brutality across the country and around the world.

Under the new administration of President Joe Biden, the Justice Department is expected to take a more assertive stance on civil rights and policing policies. During his confirmation hearing, Judge Merrick Garland, Biden's nominee for attorney general, vowed to prioritize efforts to combat racial discrimination in law enforcement.

The federal probe into Chauvin's actions could result in civil rights charges, which typically carry longer prison sentences than the state charges. However, the process was complicated last year when former Attorney General William Barr blocked a potential plea deal involving Chauvin, according to officials familiar with the matter.

The recent increase in grand jury activity may signal a renewed push by the Justice Department to hold Chauvin accountable, as part of a broader strategy to address systemic issues within police departments. This approach contrasts with the previous administration, which often took a more hands-off stance on local police conduct.

As Chauvin's state trial approaches, the federal investigation adds another layer of complexity to an already high-profile case. The outcome could have far-reaching implications for police accountability and the national conversation on race and justice in America.

Impeachment Redux: Trump Faces Accusations of Incitement Amidst Legal Hurdles

With public sentiment leaning heavily against the outgoing president, legal experts are divided on the viability of the impeachment process and the potential for future legal action.

According to a recent ABC News/Ipsos poll, an overwhelming 67 percent of Americans hold Trump responsible for the riot, while 56 percent believe he should be removed from office before his term ends on January 20th. This groundswell of public opinion underscores the political nature of impeachment, a process that allows Congress to determine guilt without having to prove legal culpability in a court of law.

Jeffrey Scott Shapiro, a former assistant attorney general for the District of Columbia, argues that Trump's speech may be protected by the First Amendment of the US Constitution. Constitutional law professor Andrew Koppelman of Northwestern University, however, acknowledges the complexity of proving Trump's intent to incite violence. Despite the political momentum behind impeachment, the legal hurdles to prosecuting Trump for incitement are formidable. Moreover, a conviction would require a two-thirds majority, a tall order given the current political climate.

President-elect Joe Biden, while acknowledging the gravity of the situation, has chosen to focus on other pressing issues, such as COVID-19 relief and economic recovery. Biden's approach reflects a desire to move the country forward, even as some Democrats advocate for pursuing legal action against Trump once he is no longer shielded by presidential immunity.

NEW YORK (AP) – The remnants of Hurricane Ida unleashed a barrage of tornadoes, powerful winds, and torrential rains on the mid-Atlantic states, leaving a trail of destruction in their wake. As the storm system moved northward, it triggered chaos in urban centers like New York and Newark, causing widespread flooding, roof collapses, and transportation disruptions.

In New Jersey, a U.S. Postal Service building saw its roof cave in under the force of the storm. "We had a significant structural failure at the Postal Service building," said Sgt. Chris Levchak, a local police officer. "It's a testament to the intensity of the winds that Ida brought."

Newark Liberty International Airport was among the hardest-hit areas, with floodwaters submerging cars and rendering roads impassable. All flights and train service were suspended as the airport turned into a virtual lake. "We've never seen anything like this before," said Scott Goldstein, Montgomery County Fire Chief. "The water rose so quickly that it caught many off guard."

Central Park in New York City recorded a staggering 3.15 inches of rain within an hour, shattering the previous one-hour record set just two weeks ago by Tropical Storm Henri. The deluge overwhelmed the city's infrastructure, inundating subway stations and tracks, forcing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to halt all service.

Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey took swift action, declaring a state of emergency in all 21 counties. "I urge everyone to stay off the roads and avoid flooded areas," he said. "The safety of our residents is our top priority."

In Pennsylvania, thousands were forced to evacuate due to dangerously high water levels at a dam near Johnstown, a city historically known as "Flood City" after a devastating flood in 1889. The Wilmore and Hinckston Run Dams, both classified as high-hazard, were closely monitored for stability amid the rising waters.

Maryland and Virginia also bore the brunt of Ida's fury, with at least one fatality reported and substantial property damage. "This storm has shown its across the region, and we are still assessing the full extent of the damage," said a Virginia emergency management official.

As the mid-Atlantic region grapples with the aftermath of Ida, attention turns to the Atlantic Ocean where Tropical Storm Larry is forming off the coast of Africa. Forecasters predict it could strengthen into a major hurricane by Saturday, underscoring the relentless nature of this year's hurricane season.

It is an honor to stand before you today, as we celebrate the indomitable spirit and profound impact of Historically Black Colleges and Universities, or HBCUs. These institutions have been, and continue to be, beacons of hope, opportunity, and excellence, nurturing generations of leaders and innovators. Today, I want to emphasize the critical role HBCUs play in our current era, particularly in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics, or STEM.

The partnership between Hampton University and NASA serves as a shining example of the power of collaboration between HBCUs and our nation's premier scientific institutions. Together, they have launched satellites that provide invaluable atmospheric data, contributing to our understanding of our planet and advancing our capabilities in space exploration. This collaboration underscores the vital role HBCUs play in national security and scientific research and development.

Contemporary global challenges, such as pandemics and climate change, are interconnected and interdependent. They demand a collective, inclusive, and innovative response. HBCUs have a storied history of addressing society's most pressing issues, and they continue to produce the trailblazers who will lead us through these complex times. By fostering a diverse pool of talent, HBCUs ensure that we have the necessary perspectives to tackle these challenges effectively.

The significance of HBCUs in educating leaders and innovators cannot be overstated. Since their inception, these institutions have been bastions of resilience, defying odds and breaking barriers. They have produced titans of industry, groundbreaking scientists, and trailblazing politicians. Investing in HBCUs is not just an investment in education; it is an investment in the strength and resilience of our nation.

President Biden's Build Back Better agenda includes historic investments in research and development, which will directly benefit HBCUs and their students. These investments will not only strengthen our STEM workforce but also ensure that we remain at the forefront of global innovation. By supporting HBCUs, we are investing in the future of our country and the well-being of our communities.

Diversity in STEM fields is not just a moral imperative; it is a strategic necessity. Women and people of color bring unique perspectives and experiences that enrich scientific inquiry and lead to more equitable outcomes. HBCUs have long been incubators for this diversity, and it is crucial that we continue to support and amplify their efforts.

As we enter the age of artificial intelligence, we must consider the importance of a diverse group of people teaching machines. Ensuring that AI reflects the full spectrum of human experiences is essential to prevent biases and promote fairness. HBCUs are poised to play a pivotal role in this endeavor, preparing the next generation of technologists and ethicists who will guide the responsible development of AI.

Support for HBCUs is not just about access to education; it is about fostering societal participation and self-determination. These institutions empower their students to shape their own futures and contribute to the betterment of their communities. HBCUs are engines of upward mobility, breaking cycles of poverty, and fostering a more equitable society.

Tom Brady's Seven Super Bowl Titles: An Unparalleled Statistical Marvel

Tom Brady, the 199th overall pick in the 2000 NFL Draft, has rewritten the record books with an unprecedented seven Super Bowl victories. This extraordinary feat has left statisticians and football experts grappling with the sheer improbability of his success, comparing it to winning the Powerball jackpot multiple times.

Vince Jansen, a renowned statistician, emphasizes the magnitude of Brady's accomplishment, stating, "The odds of a player, let alone a late-round draft pick, winning seven or more Super Bowls is akin to defying the laws of probability." According to the Pro Football Reference database, the observed probability of this happening is a staggering 1 in 26,683.

Thomas Severini, a statistics professor at Northwestern University, adds context to these numbers, saying, "If you were to randomly pick a player from the 2000 NFL draft, the chances of them winning at least seven Super Bowls would be roughly 1 in 51.8 million. That's mind-boggling."

Mark Glickman, a statistics professor at Harvard, underscores the complexity of Brady's journey, pointing out that even for a player with a guaranteed 21-year career, the probability of winning seven-plus Super Bowls is a minuscule 1 in 435,119. "When you factor in the competitiveness of the NFL and the role of luck, it's nearly unfathomable," Glickman remarks.

When narrowing the focus to quarterbacks, the probability improves slightly to 1 in 12.8 million. Abraham Wyner, a statistics professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, explains, "Assuming a player's odds of reaching the Super Bowl in a given season are 1/32, which is a generous estimation, the likelihood of achieving what Brady has is incredibly low."

The unlikelihood of another player matching Brady's seven Super Bowl titles by 2075 is estimated to be a mere 0.01%. Wyner notes, "It's not impossible, but it certainly feels like we may have witnessed a once-in-a-century, if not once-in-a-millennium, event."

The consensus among these experts is that Tom Brady's seven championship rings rank among the top five most improbable achievements in sports history. It's a testament to his unwavering dedication, skill, and an uncanny ability to defy the odds. As Jansen puts it, "Brady's journey is a testament to the power of perseverance and a reminder that in sports, as in life, the unexpected can and does happen."

Biden Administration Unveils Plan to Combat White Supremacist and Militia Violence

June 15 – President Joe Biden's administration has announced a comprehensive strategy to address the growing threat posed by white supremacist and militia groups, labeling them as top national security concerns following a domestic terrorism review. The plan focuses on increased information sharing, enhanced resources for identifying and prosecuting threats, and new measures to deter individuals from joining extremist organizations.

A senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, emphasized the urgency of the situation, stating, "We are taking a whole-of-government approach to confronting domestic terrorism, particularly from white supremacist and militia violent extremists, who have been responsible for a majority of recent attacks."

U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland announced the reinvigoration of an interagency task force to coordinate efforts against domestic terrorism, saying, "This is not a problem that any one agency can solve alone. We must work together across the government and with our partners in the private sector and in communities across the country."

The strategy, which does not propose new legislation, aims to utilize existing authority more effectively to dismantle these networks. The FBI's assessment aligns with the administration's concerns, as FBI Director Christopher Wray has previously stated that racially or ethnically motivated violent extremists, particularly those advocating for white supremacy, pose the most significant domestic violent extremist threat.

Biden's budget proposal for the next fiscal year includes an additional $100 million to train and hire analysts and prosecutors, reflecting the administration's commitment to dedicating resources and personnel to tackle the elevated threat. "We need to ensure we have the tools and resources to identify, disrupt, and hold accountable those who perpetrate acts of domestic terrorism," the senior official said.

The federal government is also enhancing screening methods to identify potential insider threats among its employees, with plans to share these techniques with private companies. The Department of Defense, in parallel, is conducting a review to determine how to remove military members involved in domestic terrorist groups, striking a balance between addressing extremism and protecting individual rights.

In outlining the strategy, the administration acknowledged the importance of partnering with state and local law enforcement, community organizations, and technology companies to combat the spread of extremist ideologies online. Garland emphasized, "We must address the root causes that lead people to turn to violence, while protecting free expression and the privacy of law-abiding Americans."

The plan underscores the Biden administration's determination to confront domestic terrorism head-on, acknowledging the evolving nature of the threat and the need for a multi-faceted response. As the nation grapples with a rise in hate-motivated violence, this strategy aims to fortify defenses against those seeking to undermine the country's democratic values.

Donald Rumsfeld's Peaceful Departure: A Stark Contrast to the Chaotic Legacy He Left Behind

Donald Rumsfeld, the former U.S. Secretary of Defense, passed away on June 29, 2021, surrounded by his family in a state of tranquility. His death, however, stands in stark contrast to the turmoil and loss of life that characterized the wars he championed as a key neoconservative architect of the Bush administration's post-9/11 foreign policy. As we reflect on Rumsfeld's life and career, it is crucial to remember the human cost of his decisions and the enduring impact they have had on the world.

Rumsfeld's tenure as Secretary of Defense, from 2001 to 2006, was marked by aggressive military interventions in Afghanistan and Iraq, both of which have resulted in countless civilian casualties. In Afghanistan, his strategies led to the deployment of controversial weapons, such as cluster bombs, which are notorious for their indiscriminate nature and the risks they pose to non-combatants long after hostilities have ceased.

Journalistic access to the frontlines was severely restricted under Rumsfeld's watch, with the Pentagon tightly controlling the flow of information to the public. This control allowed for a sanitized narrative of the wars, obscuring the harsh realities faced by civilians and soldiers alike. The manipulation of information made it difficult for the American public to fully grasp the human toll of the conflicts.

One of Rumsfeld's most contentious decisions was the invasion of Iraq in 2003, which he fervently pushed for, even before the dust had settled in Afghanistan. The Bush administration, with Rumsfeld at the helm, opportunistically used the tragedy of 9/11 as a justification for targeting Iraq, despite a lack of evidence linking Saddam Hussein's regime to the terrorist attacks.

Rumsfeld's interest in regime change in Iraq was not a newfound obsession; it was a decades-long pursuit. In the 1980s, during his first stint as Secretary of Defense under President Gerald Ford, Rumsfeld was instrumental in cultivating ties with Saddam Hussein. The U.S. provided arms and intelligence to Iraq, then engaged in a conflict with Iran, effectively supporting a dictator who would later become a nemesis.

The irony of Rumsfeld's past support for Saddam Hussein was not lost on critics when the Iraq War was being prepared. The revelation of these ties added fuel to the fire of opposition against the invasion, raising questions about the true motives behind U.S. foreign policy and the credibility of the Bush administration's justifications.

Throughout his career, Rumsfeld was a polarizing figure, with admirers praising his decisiveness and critics decrying his disdain for international law and diplomacy. His legacy is marred by the deaths of hundreds of thousands of civilians, the displacement of millions, and the destabilization of entire regions. The wars he helped launch continue to reverberate in the form of ongoing conflicts, migration crises, and a global rise in terrorism.

CNN – Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd, pleaded not guilty to federal charges related to the alleged use of unreasonable force on a 14-year-old teenager in 2017. The arraignment took place via video conference from Oak Park Heights, a maximum-security prison in Minnesota, where Chauvin is currently serving a 22 1/2-year sentence for Floyd's murder.

These new charges are distinct from Chauvin's state conviction and focus on an incident in September 2017. The federal grand jury indictment accuses Chauvin of striking the teenager with a flashlight and kneeling on his neck and back during an arrest, thereby depriving him of his constitutional right to be free from unreasonable force by a law enforcement officer.

In addition to the charges involving the 14-year-old, Chauvin, along with ex-officers Thomas Lane, J. Alexander Kueng, and Tou Thao, pleaded not guilty to federal civil rights charges connected to the death of George Floyd. The May 2020 incident, which was captured on video, showed Chauvin kneeling on Floyd's neck for more than nine minutes, sparking global protests against police brutality and racial injustice.

The federal indictment accuses all four former officers of violating Floyd's constitutional rights by failing to provide him with medical aid and by not intervening in Chauvin's use of excessive force. The case has brought increased scrutiny to police practices and sparked calls for police reform across the United States.

Chauvin's trial and conviction for second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter in Floyd's death marked a rare instance of a police officer being held criminally accountable for an on-duty death. The verdict was seen as a significant moment in the ongoing conversation about race and law enforcement in America.

Meanwhile, Thao, Kueng, and Lane still face separate state charges of aiding and abetting second-degree murder and aiding and abetting second-degree manslaughter in connection with Floyd's death. Their trial is expected to take place later this year.

The federal case against Chauvin and the three other former officers underscores the ongoing efforts to address police misconduct and hold law enforcement accountable for actions that violate citizens' rights. As the legal proceedings continue, the nation remains watchful, with many seeking justice and systemic change in the wake of George Floyd's tragic death.

KANDAHAR, Afghanistan – At least 50 people were killed and over 100 wounded in a suicide bombing at a Shiite mosque in Kandahar city on Friday, marking the second major attack in Afghanistan within a week and fueling concerns about the resurgence of militant groups under the Taliban's rule.

The attack, which took place during Friday prayers, saw multiple explosions and gunfire, according to eyewitnesses. Abdul Jabar Karimi, a local shopkeeper, described the chaotic scene: "There was a loud explosion, then gunfire. People were running in all directions, trying to save themselves."

The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) condemned the attack, putting the death toll at 30, with many more injured. In a statement, the mission expressed its "deepest condolences" to the families of the victims and called for an immediate end to the targeting of civilians.

No group has claimed responsibility for the Kandahar bombing, but the Islamic State, which has a history of targeting Shiites, claimed a similar attack on a mosque in Kunduz last week that left more than 100 dead. The extremist group considers Shiites heretics and has carried out several attacks on their places of worship in the past.

The incident comes a day after a Taliban police chief was killed by the Islamic State in Konar province, further highlighting the challenges the new regime faces in controlling other militant outfits, including Al-Qaeda. Taliban police commander Abdul Ghafar Mohammadi vowed retaliation, stating, "We will not rest until we arrest those responsible for this big crime."

Health director for the province, Hafiz Abdul Hai Abbas, said the city's hospitals were overwhelmed with casualties. "We have received more than 50 dead bodies and over 100 injured people," he told reporters. "The situation is critical, and we fear the death toll may rise."

The Taliban, which took control of Afghanistan in August following the withdrawal of U.S. forces, has vowed to restore peace and security. However, the recent attacks have raised questions about their ability to fulfill this promise. Murtaza Khaledi, another eyewitness at the Kandahar mosque, expressed his fear: "We thought the Taliban's return would bring peace, but it seems like the war is far from over."

As Afghanistan's new rulers grapple with the mounting security challenges, international observers are watching closely to see if the Taliban can prevent the country from becoming a breeding ground for terrorism. The Taliban has repeatedly assured the international community that it will not allow Afghanistan to be used for attacks on other countries.

Tiger Woods Suffers Serious Injuries in Car Accident, Golfing Future in Jeopardy

Tiger Woods, the legendary golfer, was involved in a harrowing car accident on February 23, 2021, just outside Los Angeles. The incident, which left Woods with severe leg injuries, has raised concerns about the future of his storied golfing career. According to Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva, Woods was not under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time of the crash but was reportedly speeding, contributing to the severity of the accident.

Woods sustained "open and comminuted fractures" in his tibia and fibula, requiring immediate surgery. Medical professionals inserted rods, pins, and screws to stabilize his injuries. "I want to thank everyone for the overwhelming support and messages during this tough time," Woods said in a statement. "I am currently in good spirits and continuing to focus on my recovery. I appreciate your concern and well wishes."

The 15-time major champion, who had recently undergone his fifth spinal surgery in December 2020, had already placed his professional career on hold. Despite the gravity of his current situation, former PGA Tour player Bill Mallon offered a note of optimism, suggesting that Woods could make a return to the golf course within a year. "Tiger is a fighter, and I wouldn't count him out just yet," Mallon said. "He has shown resilience and determination throughout his career, and I believe he will work tirelessly to get back on the course."

The accident serves as a stark reminder of the importance of vehicular safety and the potential impact of injuries on even the most accomplished athletes. Sheriff Villanueva emphasized the need for caution on the roads, stating, "Speed was a factor in this collision, and it's fortunate that Mr. Woods was able to come out of this alive."

As Woods recuperates, the golfing world waits anxiously for updates on his progress. His incredible achievements, including 82 PGA Tour victories and 14 professional major championships, have solidified his status as one of the greatest golfers of all time. The road to recovery may be long, but Woods' indomitable spirit and unwavering determination will undoubtedly guide him through this challenging period.

Fall River Police Apologize for Controversial Facebook Post on George Floyd, Officer Reassigned

The Fall River Police Department in Massachusetts has issued a public apology after a controversial Facebook post criticized George Floyd and seemingly defended former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin, who was convicted of murdering Floyd. According to Chief Cardoza, the post was made by an officer who believed they were re-posting the content to their personal page. The officer has since been reassigned to non-public-contact duties while an external investigator looks into the matter. Cardoza emphasized that the department takes full responsibility for the incident and is committed to learning from it.

Fall River Mayor Paul Coogan also weighed in on the controversy, acknowledging the officer's remorse. "The officer involved is deeply sorry and recognizes that he has let the community down," Coogan said. "We take these matters seriously, and appropriate disciplinary actions will be considered as the investigation unfolds."

The controversial post referenced Chauvin's verdict, suggesting that Floyd should have cooperated with the police in the same way Chauvin did during his own arrest. This ignited a firestorm of criticism from the public, who saw the post as insensitive and out of touch with the ongoing national conversation about police reform and racial justice.

In response to the incident, Chief Cardoza highlighted the department's ongoing training initiatives aimed at promoting fair and equitable policing. "We are constantly working to ensure our officers understand the importance of empathy and professionalism in their interactions with the public," he said.

As the investigation continues, the Fall River Police Department is expected to take appropriate measures to address the situation and reinforce its commitment to community policing. The incident serves as a reminder of the ongoing need for transparency and accountability within law enforcement agencies.

Released ISIS-K Bomber Behind Kabul Airport Attack: A Fallout of Chaotic US Withdrawal

In the harrowing aftermath of the August 26 suicide bombing at Kabul's Hamid Karzai International Airport, which claimed the lives of 13 American service members and scores of Afghan civilians, new details have emerged about the attacker's identity and the circumstances that led to his freedom. Abdul Rehman Al-Loghri, the ISIS-K bomber, was confirmed by two US officials and Rep. Ken Calvert (California Republican) to have been among the prisoners released from Parwan prison near Kabul just days before the deadly assault.

H-E-B Temporarily Closes Texas Stores Amid Winter Storm Uri's Devastating Impact

San Antonio, TX – Grocery retailer H-E-B has taken the unprecedented step of temporarily closing some of its Texas stores and adjusting operating hours in response to Winter Storm Uri, which has wreaked havoc across the Lone Star State. The affected areas include greater Houston, North East region, Gulf Coast, Austin, Central Texas, and San Antonio, all of which have been grappling with extreme weather conditions, power outages, and water shortages.

In an effort to conserve energy and support the strained Texas energy grid, most H-E-B stores are now opening at 9 or 10 a.m. and closing as early as 5 to 7 p.m. The pharmacy hours align with these adjusted store hours, ensuring that customers can still access essential medications during this challenging time.

In Austin, Central Texas, and San Antonio, several H-E-B locations have been forced to close entirely due to the severity of the weather. The closures come as millions of Texans face the coldest temperatures in decades, with many still without power or access to safe drinking water. The company's decision to shorten store hours or shut down operations altogether is a reflection of the extraordinary circumstances created by the storm.

The extreme weather conditions have also disrupted H-E-B's supply chain, leading to limited product assortments and purchase limits at some stores. The retailer acknowledged that Winter Storm Uri has caused severe disruptions to the food supply chain, making it difficult to maintain regular inventory levels. H-E-B is working diligently to replenish stocks and ensure that essential items remain available for customers.

In light of the ongoing crisis, H-E-B has temporarily suspended its online grocery services, including curbside pickup and home delivery. The company understands the inconvenience this may cause but emphasizes the need to prioritize in-store operations and conserve energy during this state of emergency.

"We are committed to serving our communities during this unprecedented event," said Scott McClelland, H-E-B's President. "The safety of our customers, partners, and the communities we serve is our top priority. Customers are encouraged to check H-E-B's website and social media channels for the most up-to-date information on store hours and availability. The company is urging Texans to stay safe, conserve resources, and look out for one another during this historic winter storm.

Missing Long Island Woman Gabrielle Petito's Family Fears for Her Safety During Cross-Country Trip

BLUE POINT, Long Island (WABC) – The family of 22-year-old Gabrielle "Gabby" Petito from Long Island is frantically searching for answers after she vanished while on a cross-country trip with her boyfriend in Wyoming. Petito's mother, Nicole Schmidt, is expressing deep concern and fear for her daughter's well-being.

Petito and her boyfriend, whose identity has not been disclosed, were traveling in a white 2012 Ford Transit van, documenting their adventures on YouTube under the banner "Van Life." The couple had planned to reach Portland, Oregon, in October. However, Schmidt received a text message from her daughter on August 30, and that was the last communication she had with Petito.

"I just want her home safe," Schmidt said, her voice filled with emotion. "This is not like her. She would always stay in touch, even if she didn't have service, she would find a way to let us know she was okay."

Petito's disappearance was reported to the Suffolk County Police Department on September 11, nearly two weeks after the last known communication. The North Port Police Department confirmed that Petito's boyfriend is not missing and that the couple's van was recovered in Florida.

"We are treating this as a missing person case," said the North Port Police Department in a statement. "We are asking anyone who may have had contact with Gabrielle or saw her van in the area of Grand Teton National Park between August 24 and August 30 to contact us."

Gabrielle Petito is described as a white female, approximately 5-foot-5 inches tall, weighing 110 pounds, with blonde hair and blue eyes. She has several distinctive tattoos, including a quote on her left arm that reads, "let it be" and a design on her right arm.

The FBI Tampa Field Office is actively assisting in the investigation, and local police are urging the public to come forward with any information that could help locate Petito. "We are pleading with anyone who may have seen something, no matter how small, to please contact Crime Stoppers or the North Port Police Department," said an FBI spokesperson.

As the search for Petito continues, her family remains hopeful for her safe return. "Gabby, if you're out there, just let us know you're okay," Schmidt pleaded. "We love you, and we just want you home."

Anyone with information on Gabrielle Petito's whereabouts is encouraged to contact the North Port Police Department at (941) 429-7382 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS (8477).

US Banks Distribute $1,400 Stimulus Checks as IRS Approaches $388B Milestone, With Talks of a Fourth Round on the Horizon

Major banks across the United States have begun distributing $1,400 stimulus checks to millions of households in March, providing much-needed relief amidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has been at the forefront of this effort, having sent over 165 million payments, amounting to a staggering $388 billion, with the latest batch scheduled for an official payment date of May 12.

As part of the American Rescue Plan, the IRS prioritized individuals who had filed their 2019 or 2020 tax returns, as well as those receiving government benefits, such as Social Security recipients. "The IRS has been diligently working to ensure that eligible individuals receive their stimulus payments as quickly and efficiently as possible," said Charlie Wise, head of global research and consulting at TransUnion.

In an effort to rectify underpayments, over 460,000 "plus-up" payments have been dispatched to individuals who were entitled to more than they initially received. Additionally, nearly 500,000 more payments have been sent to those who recently filed their tax returns. Half of the latest round of payments were made through direct deposit, while the remaining half were sent via mail in the form of checks or pre-paid debit cards.

The possibility of a fourth round of stimulus payments is under consideration by lawmakers, as 38% of the population reports that their household income is still affected by the pandemic. "The ongoing financial impact of the pandemic underscores the need for continued support," Wise commented.

The IRS has reopened its "Get My Payment" website, allowing individuals to track the status of their $1,400 checks. The portal displays various statuses, from processed payments to notifications that more information is required. However, issues such as outdated addresses or bank information can hinder payment delivery. The agency encourages taxpayers to file their 2020 tax returns with current details to avoid any potential delays.

It's important to note that pre-paid debit cards issued for previous stimulus payments will not be reloaded with the latest round of funds. Instead, a new card or an alternative payment method will be issued. If the IRS encounters outdated bank account information, the payment may be delayed, but returned funds will eventually be sent via a mailed check or pre-paid debit card.

President Biden Urges Intensified Efforts to Uncover COVID-19 Origins, Calls for China's Transparency

Washington, D.C. - President Joe Biden has underscored the critical need to investigate the origins of COVID-19, reiterating his commitment to understanding the roots of the pandemic that has affected the world for over a year. In a statement, the President highlighted his early call for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to gain access to China in order to better comprehend the virus.

Despite these efforts, Biden acknowledged the challenges faced in getting inspectors on the ground in China during the initial stages of the outbreak. Undeterred, he tasked the Intelligence Community (IC) with preparing a comprehensive report on the possible origins of the virus shortly after taking office in March. The IC's preliminary report presented two plausible scenarios but fell short of reaching a conclusive determination.

He has set a 90-day deadline for the intelligence agencies to provide a more definitive conclusion. This intensified investigation will involve posing specific questions to the Chinese government, seeking transparency and cooperation in the pursuit of global public health.

To bolster the IC's work, Biden has enlisted the support of multiple government agencies, including National Labs, which will collaborate in this comprehensive effort. The President emphasized the importance of working with international partners to put collective pressure on China for a transparent and thorough investigation. This collaborative approach underscores the global nature of the pandemic and the shared responsibility to uncover the truth.

The White House remains steadfast in its pursuit of answers, emphasizing that understanding the origins of COVID-19 is not only a matter of scientific curiosity but also a critical step in preventing future pandemics and protecting the health and safety of people worldwide.

Ever Given Partially Refloated: Suez Canal Blockage Eases, But Impact on Global Trade Lingers

In a significant development, one of the world's largest container ships, the Ever Given, was partially refloated in the Suez Canal after running aground due to a loss of steering capability during a dust storm and high winds. The mammoth vessel, which had been blocking a crucial lane in the canal for several days, was successfully freed with the assistance of eight tugboats, highlighting the strategic importance of the waterway for international trade.

The blockage of the canal, which sees about 50 ships a day pass through on average in 2019, has disrupted Asia-Europe trade, causing a backlog of vessels waiting to navigate the vital shipping route. According to Jamil Sayegh, a former captain and maritime law specialist, "The Suez Canal is a lifeline for global trade, and this incident underscores its significance."

Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement, the technical manager of the Ever Given, confirmed that all 25 crew members were safe throughout the ordeal. However, the implications of the blockage continue to reverberate, with a growing number of tankers carrying millions of barrels of crude oil idling at either end of the canal.

Reevaluating Colin Powell's Legacy: A Call for Social Justice in Education and Military Spending

As we reflect on Powell's life and impact, it is crucial to consider the lasting consequences of his decisions, particularly on education and the lives of marginalized communities.

Professor Clarence Lusane of Howard University weighs in, stating, "Powell's doctrine was meant to restrain the use of military force, but in practice, it didn't always achieve that goal." One such example is the 1989 U.S. invasion of Panama, where Powell, as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, oversaw an operation that resulted in significant civilian casualties and destruction.

However, Powell's most controversial moment came in 2003 when, as Secretary of State, he presented false intelligence to the United Nations to justify the invasion of Iraq. This war, devoid of clear objectives and exit strategies, led to the loss of hundreds of thousands of lives. Lusane adds, "Powell's role in the Iraq War was a tragic misstep that contributed to the destabilization of the region and the suffering of countless people."

The Iraq War also indirectly affected domestic policies, such as the introduction of tuition at the City University of New York (CUNY) during a financial crisis exacerbated by soaring military expenditure. Hebh Jamal, a Colin Powell School alumnus, expresses her concerns, saying, "It's hard to reconcile the school's commitment to social justice with the honoring of someone who played a significant role in diverting resources from education to war."

The Colin Powell School at City College of New York, named in his honor, has faced criticism from students and alumni who argue that the institution should not celebrate a figure whose actions had a detrimental impact on marginalized communities, especially Muslim and Arab American students. Jamal adds, "For many of us, Powell's name is a constant reminder of the harm inflicted on our families and communities."

This controversy raises important questions about the role of educational institutions in honoring controversial figures. Should they distance themselves from individuals whose legacies are marred by actions that contradict the values they claim to uphold? The answer lies in prioritizing social spending over military investment, as advocated by Jamal: "We need to invest in education, healthcare, and infrastructure, not wars that only create more harm."

In reevaluating Colin Powell's legacy, we must acknowledge the human cost of his decisions, particularly in the Iraq War. By doing so, we can learn from the past and work towards a future where education and social justice take precedence over military interventions. As Lusane suggests, "It's time to critically examine the impact of our leaders' actions and ensure that our institutions reflect the values we aspire to as a society."

This protection ensures that the relief money goes directly to the intended recipients, providing them with much-needed financial stability during these challenging times.

California Governor Gavin Newsom has championed the California Comeback Plan, which encompasses a wide range of measures designed to accelerate the state's economic recovery. Stacey Plaskett Makes History as First Delegate on Impeachment Managers Team

Despite the court's ruling, a temporary restraining order remains in effect, allowing Citibank a window to appeal the decision. The bank has expressed its intention to do so, maintaining that it is entitled to recover the误转 funds. Washington CNN – FBI Director Chris Wray testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday, forcefully debunking the notion that the January 6 Capitol rioters were "fake Trump protesters" or that left-wing group Antifa was involved in the violence. The hearing shed light on the ongoing investigation into the insurrection and the challenges faced by law enforcement in sharing intelligence.

Addressing the committee, Wray said, "We have not to this point seen any evidence of anarchist extremist groups, such as Antifa, playing a role in the events of January 6." He emphasized that the majority of the over 260 defendants charged in federal court for their roles in the siege have shown allegiance to former President Donald Trump.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Dick Durbin, a Democrat from Illinois, thanked Wray for his testimony, saying, "I think it's important that the American people understand the facts as you present them, unvarnished and straightforward."

Wray also refuted former President Trump's persistent claims of widespread voter fraud in the 2020 election, stating, "We have not seen evidence of fraud that would have affected the outcome of the election." This statement underscores the FBI's position that there is no evidence to support the claims that have been widely promoted by Trump and some of his allies.

However, Wray's testimony was not without criticism. Connecticut Senator Richard Blumenthal expressed disappointment that the FBI director did not denounce lawmakers who endorse QAnon conspiracy theories. "I think it's important for the FBI director to speak truth to power," Blumenthal said, questioning why Wray would not condemn elected officials who amplify such theories.

In defense of the FBI's actions leading up to the Capitol attack, Wray defended the sharing of the "Norfolk memo," an intelligence report that warned of potential violence on January 6. The memo was shared with law enforcement, including the Capitol Police, through email, a verbal briefing, and a law enforcement portal. Wray acknowledged, however, that he did not see the Norfolk report until after the attack, highlighting the challenge of intelligence sharing across departments.

"We recognize we do not have all the answers yet, and we are deeply committed to getting them," Wray said, acknowledging the need for improved intelligence gathering and sharing in the face of domestic extremist threats.

Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican, pressed Wray on the FBI's handling of the Norfolk memo, suggesting that more could have been done to prevent the Capitol breach. Wray responded, "The FBI stands ready to learn all the lessons we can from what happened on January 6, and we are committed to working with our partners to ensure it never happens again."

His dedication to public service, his commitment to bipartisanship, and his trailblazing accomplishments made him a role model for many.
