CNN – A coalition of media outlets, including CNN, has sued for access to unreleased videos from the January 6 insurrection at the US Capitol, seeking to shed light on the severity of the violent crimes committed during the riot. Last week, the public gained a glimpse of the harrowing footage, which included surveillance clips and body camera recordings from police officers, depicting a chaotic and brutal scene.

The Justice Department and federal courts had initially withheld the footage, citing security concerns and the potential impact on fair trials for the defendants. However, as videos began to surface in court proceedings, the extent of the violence against law enforcement officers became increasingly apparent. DC Police Officer Michael Fanone, who was injured during the riot, said, "The footage shows the true nature of the attack on the Capitol and the bravery of the officers who stood in the line of duty."

Judge Royce Lamberth, presiding over one of the cases, emphasized the importance of transparency, stating, "The public has a right to see what happened that day." This sentiment was echoed by Judge Michael Aloi, who granted access to some footage in another case, arguing that the public's interest in understanding the events outweighed any potential harm.

Gabe Roth, Executive Director of Fix the Court, a judicial watchdog group, underscored the role of visual evidence in holding those responsible accountable. "These videos are crucial to understanding the gravity of the crimes committed and the impact on our democracy," he said.

CNN Lawyer Drew Shenkman highlighted the media's commitment to transparency, explaining, "We believe the public has a right to see these videos and understand the events of January 6 more fully."

Nonetheless, some defendants have contested the release of the footage, fearing it could prejudice their right to a fair trial. Charles Tobin, an attorney at Ballard Spahr, representing one of the defendants, argued, "The release of these videos could taint the jury pool and compromise our client's right to a fair and impartial jury."

Despite these objections, more than a dozen video access requests from the media coalition remain pending. In some instances, the Justice Department has requested to block the rebroadcasting of the footage. As the legal battle continues, investigators are still working to identify over 250 individuals believed to have been involved in violent or assaultive behavior against police during the riot.

Judge Emmet Sullivan, overseeing another case, acknowledged the delicate balance between transparency and the rights of the accused. "We must ensure that justice is served without compromising the integrity of the legal process," he said.

The release of the videos has reignited discussions around the violence inflicted by Trump supporters on law enforcement that day. The footage serves as a stark reminder of the chaos that unfolded, with officers like Fanone being beaten and overwhelmed by the mob.

Justin Thomas Offers Insight into Tiger Woods' Recovery and Potential Golf Return

On a recent episode of the No Laying Up podcast, professional golfer Justin Thomas opened up about his friend and fellow golfer Tiger Woods' ongoing recovery from a life-threatening car accident earlier this year. Thomas painted a picture of a resilient Woods who remains optimistic about his future in the sport while prioritizing his role as a father.

"Tiger's in good spirits," Thomas shared. "He's still doing his dad stuff with [Charlie and Sam], which is awesome to see. Obviously, he's not able to do as much as he wants to, but he's still able to be a dad, which I know means the world to him."

In February, Woods survived a severe car accident that left him with significant orthopedic injuries to his right leg. Since then, the 15-time major champion has been on a long road to recovery, focusing on physical therapy and regaining his strength.

While Thomas is uncertain about Woods' return to the PGA Tour, he emphasized that Woods would only come back if he felt he could compete at the highest level. "If he can't play at a high level, he's not going to play," Thomas said. "He's not going to come back just to play. He's going to come back to try to win golf tournaments."

According to a source close to Woods, the golfer's primary focus has been on his role as a father to his children, Charlie and Sam. "Being a dad has really helped him stay focused on his recovery," the source shared with PEOPLE.

Woods' recovery has been nothing short of remarkable, with a source close to the golfer revealing, "He's made incredible progress and is feeling strong and healthy." This optimism is echoed by another insider, who claims Woods is "very optimistic about getting back out on the tour."

Despite the encouraging updates, the specifics of Woods' return timeline remain unclear. "There's a timeframe in his mind, but he's not sharing that with anyone," the insider said.

Recalling the details of the February accident, Woods was driving at a high speed when his car veered off the road, rolled over several times, and landed on its side. The accident left Woods with compound fractures in his right leg, requiring extensive surgery and a long rehabilitation process.

As Woods continues his journey back to the golf course, fans and fellow golfers alike eagerly await any news of his potential return. Justin Thomas' insights offer a glimpse into Woods' mindset and priorities, highlighting the golfer's determination and the unwavering support of his family and friends.

KABUL, Afghanistan – Qatar's Foreign Minister Mohammad bin Abdulrahman Al Thani has warned that the reopening of Kabul's Hamid Karzai International Airport for commercial flights remains uncertain, as experts from Qatar and Turkey work diligently to restore operations following the U.S. withdrawal.

"Technical teams from Qatar and Turkey are on the ground to assess and repair the damages at Kabul airport," Al Thani said. "However, it is unclear when the airport will be fully operational for regular flights."

The Taliban's swift takeover of Afghanistan has raised global concerns about their previous record of human rights abuses, particularly towards women. However, the group has pledged to allow women and girls to attend school and maintain freedom of movement. "We assure all Afghans that their rights will be protected," a Taliban spokesperson said.

In the western city of Herat, dozens of brave women took to the streets to demand their rights, including representation in the Taliban's future Cabinet. Friba Kabrzani, a protest organizer, said, "We want to be part of the decision-making process. Our presence here is a message to the Taliban that we will not be silenced."

Maryam Ebram, a participant in the demonstration, echoed Kabrzani's sentiment, stating, "We want to see real actions, not just empty promises. Our fight for rights will continue."

The recent suicide bombing at the airport during the chaotic evacuation process claimed the lives of 169 Afghans and 13 U.S. service members, underscoring the security challenges that lie ahead. The closure of the airport has left many Afghans who fear the Taliban stranded, unable to flee the country, and has delayed much-needed humanitarian aid.

Qatar, which played a crucial role in facilitating talks between the U.S. and the Taliban, remains committed to engaging with the new regime. Al Thani expressed hope for a positive outcome, saying, "We believe dialogue is the only way forward to ensure the stability and well-being of the Afghan people."

UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab echoed this sentiment, emphasizing the international community's need to verify the Taliban's commitments. "We have to judge the Taliban by their actions, not their words," Raab said. "It's essential that we engage with them to hold them to account on the promises they've made."

As the world watches Afghanistan with a mix of hope and skepticism, the determination of women like Kabrzani and Ebram signals that the fight for rights and freedom will not be easily extinguished. The reopening of Kabul's airport, and the international community's engagement with the Taliban, will play a crucial role in shaping the country's future.

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle: A Journey Through Pain, Healing, and Love in 'The Me You Can't See'

In his deeply personal Apple TV+ docuseries, "The Me You Can't See," Prince Harry opens up about the challenging times he and his wife, Meghan Markle, have faced, particularly in the aftermath of bullying allegations that surfaced just ahead of their groundbreaking Oprah interview. The Duke of Sussex shares intimate details about the impact of these allegations on Meghan, as well as the role therapy has played in their healing process.

The Times reported last year that Meghan faced a bullying complaint from a close aide during her tenure as a senior royal, a claim she fervently denied. Speaking in the docuseries, Harry reveals the emotional toll these allegations took on his wife, painting a poignant picture of her distress: "I've seen what happens when someone I love is commoditised to the point that they are no longer treated or seen as a real person. I lost my mother and now I watch my wife falling victim to the same powerful forces."

Describing Meghan's emotional state, Harry says, "I watched her crying, and I've seen her cry so many times in our house. But that's not the point. The point is that she never should have been put in that position." The Duke credits Meghan for being a source of strength, encouraging him to confront his own mental health struggles and seek therapy.

"Without question, our relationship has been massively under attack," Harry shares. "From her, I was able to go, 'Okay, I need to fix this. I need to fix this because I can't begin to imagine what it must have been like for her going through this process by herself all those years ago.' And because of that, I was able to start unpacking all of the stuff that I had never processed before."

Through therapy, Harry says he has been able to address unresolved issues from his childhood, including the loss of his mother, Princess Diana. He emphasizes the transformative power of mental health support, stating, "Therapy has enabled me to handle anything. Because of the work I've done over the last four years, I feel like I'm in a position now where I can put my hand on my heart and say, 'I'm in a good place.'"

Since stepping down as working royals in March 2020, the couple has settled into their new life in Montecito, California, where they are raising their son, Archie, and eagerly awaiting the arrival of their second child, a girl. They have also embarked on various professional ventures, including partnerships with Netflix, Spotify, and their philanthropic organization, the Archewell Foundation.

As they recently celebrated their third wedding anniversary, Harry and Meghan continue to navigate the complexities of their new roles while advocating for mental health awareness. A spokesperson for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex echoes their commitment, stating, "Through their work, Harry and Meghan aim to shine a light on the importance of mental health and well-being, especially in these challenging times."

Post-9/11 Figures: Journeys from Heroes to Controversial Icons

In the aftermath of the September 11th attacks, a group of public figures emerged as symbols of resilience and leadership. From Rudy Giuliani to Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, their trajectories have been marked by both accolades and controversy. As the world reflects on the two decades since that fateful day, it's worth examining how these individuals' legacies have evolved.

Rudolph Giuliani, once hailed as "America's Mayor" for his stoic response to the attacks, has seen his image transform in recent years. Following his tenure as New York City Mayor, Giuliani became a controversial figure due to his association with former President Donald Trump and his own legal troubles. His vocal support for Trump's baseless claims of election fraud has further polarized public opinion.

Bernard Kerik, the former New York City Police Commissioner, was lauded for his role in the 9/11 response. However, his political aspirations were derailed by legal issues, which led to a prison sentence. In 2019, President Trump pardoned Kerik, bringing him back into the public eye, albeit with a tarnished reputation.

George W. Bush, the 43rd President of the United States, saw his approval ratings soar in the wake of 9/11. He launched the War on Terrorism, which included the invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq. Since leaving office, Bush has largely retreated from politics, focusing on painting and occasional public appearances that often emphasize unity.

Richard Cheney, Bush's Vice President, was a strong advocate for military intervention post-9/11. Cheney's hawkish stance remains a subject of debate. His daughter, Liz Cheney, has become a controversial figure within the Republican Party due to her vocal opposition to Trump and his influence.

Colin Powell, the first Black Secretary of State, initially supported the Iraq War but later distanced himself from the Bush administration. Powell's disillusionment with the Republican Party grew during the Trump era, and he ultimately endorsed Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election.

Condoleezza Rice, who served as National Security Advisor and later Secretary of State, has transitioned to academia since leaving office. She currently holds positions at Stanford University, focusing on teaching and research.

John Ashcroft, Attorney General under Bush, oversaw the implementation of the USA PATRIOT Act, a controversial piece of legislation that expanded law enforcement powers. After leaving government, Ashcroft entered the private sector, working as a lobbyist and consultant.

John Yoo, a former Justice Department official, played a crucial role in crafting legal justifications for the war on terrorism, including the use of enhanced interrogation techniques. Yoo continues to defend strong presidential powers and is a professor at the University of California, Berkeley.

WHO Statement: COVID-19 Vaccines for Children, Prioritization, and Considerations

The World Health Organization (WHO) acknowledges the growing authorization of COVID-19 vaccines for use in children, as several countries have granted emergency use approval for younger age groups. While the primary focus remains on vaccinating older individuals and those with comorbidities, the role of pediatric vaccination is becoming increasingly relevant in the global response to the pandemic.

COVID-19 continues to disproportionately affect older populations and individuals with underlying health conditions. The WHO emphasizes the importance of prioritizing vaccination for these high-risk groups to protect them from severe illness, hospitalization, and death. However, the organization also recognizes the need to address the impact of the virus on children and adolescents.

Children and adolescents generally experience milder symptoms of COVID-19 compared to adults, but this does not negate the potential risks associated with the disease. Younger children, particularly those under five years of age, may be at a higher risk of illnesses with symptoms similar to COVID-19, necessitating careful monitoring.

Long COVID-19 and Pediatric Inflammatory Multisystem Syndrome (PIMS-TS or MIS-C) are two concerns for children and adolescents post-infection. Long COVID-19 refers to the persistence of symptoms beyond the initial recovery period, while PIMS-TS/MIS-C is a rare but severe hyperinflammatory condition linked to COVID-19.

Risk factors for severe COVID-19 in children include older age, obesity, and preexisting medical conditions. In low to middle-income countries, there may be a larger impact of pediatric COVID-19-related fatalities due to limited healthcare resources and higher prevalence of these risk factors.

The role of children and adolescents in the transmission of COVID-19 remains an area of ongoing research. Studies have produced mixed results, with some suggesting that younger children may be less infectious than adolescents and adults. However, more evidence is needed to fully understand their contribution to the spread of the virus.

Beyond the direct health implications, the COVID-19 pandemic has had significant socio-economic consequences for children and adolescents worldwide. School closures, social isolation, and disruptions to essential services have affected their education, mental health, and overall well-being. The WHO underscores the importance of considering these broader impacts when making decisions about pediatric vaccination and public health measures.

In light of these factors, the WHO continues to monitor the evolving scientific evidence and collaborate with global partners to provide guidance on the safe and effective use of COVID-19 vaccines in children and adolescents. This includes evaluating the benefits and risks, as well as ensuring equitable access to vaccines for all populations, regardless of age.

As more data becomes available, the WHO will update its recommendations to ensure that the global response to the pandemic remains evidence-based and responsive to the needs of all individuals, including the youngest members of society. The organization remains committed to supporting countries in their efforts to protect public health and mitigate the far-reaching effects of COVID-19 on children and adolescents.

Fact Check: GOP Falsely Blames Biden for Gas, Lumber Price Increases

WASHINGTON (AP) – House Republican leaders have been asserting that President Joe Biden's policies are responsible for the recent spikes in gasoline and lumber costs, a claim that does not hold up under scrutiny. Critics argue that these price increases are largely due to factors unrelated to the Biden administration, such as the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic and a cyberattack on a major pipeline.

Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican Leader, has accused Biden of "causing this pain at the pump" through his executive actions, including the cancellation of the Keystone XL pipeline permit. However, experts point out that the pipeline, which would have carried crude oil, not gasoline, would not have had an immediate impact on current gas prices.

Liz Cheney, a Republican representative from Wyoming, echoed McCarthy's sentiment, tweeting, "Biden's war on American energy is causing prices to soar." But Gas Buddy's head of petroleum analysis, Patrick DeHaan, clarifies, "The Colonial Pipeline cyberattack is the main culprit for the rise in gas prices, not any policy from the Biden administration."

The recent increase in gas prices is directly tied to the shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline, which supplies nearly half of the East Coast's fuel. Following a ransomware attack, the pipeline was offline for days, leading to panic buying and temporary shortages, not Biden's energy policies. DeHaan notes, "The rapid bounce-back in demand and lingering issues from the Colonial Pipeline shutdown have contributed to higher prices, not the White House's actions."

When comparing current gas prices to last year, it's crucial to consider the context of the pandemic. Prices plummeted in 2020 due to reduced demand as millions of Americans stayed home, not because of any Trump administration policies. Ronna McDaniel, head of the Republican National Committee, tweeted about a 400% increase in lumber prices, blaming Biden's "radical agenda." However, this ignores the fact that lumber prices have surged due to a combination of factors, including a sharp economic rebound and increased demand for home improvement projects.

Patrick DeHaan adds, "Lumber prices have risen due to a perfect storm of events, including strong consumer demand, supply chain disruptions, and mills struggling to keep up. These factors have nothing to do with the president's policies." The housing market's robust recovery, fueled by low interest rates and a desire for more space during the pandemic, has led to a surge in demand for lumber, causing prices to skyrocket.

While the Colonial Pipeline has resumed operations, some states continue to experience gasoline shortages, a direct result of the cyberattack, not Biden's energy policies. Similarly, lumber prices remain high as the industry works to catch up with the unexpectedly strong demand.

LAPLACE, La. – Nine days after Hurricane Ida slammed into Louisiana, hundreds of thousands of residents remain in the dark, grappling with a slow and uneven power restoration process that has fueled frustration across the state. As of Tuesday, about 250,000 customers were still without electricity, according to Entergy Louisiana.

State Rep. Tanner Magee, the House's second-ranking Republican, expressed concern over the disparities in power restoration between New Orleans, which has seen significant progress, and other hard-hit communities. "The fact that we have folks in New Orleans with power while folks just 30 miles away are still in the dark is unacceptable," Magee said.

Adding to the distress, the Louisiana Health Department revoked the licenses of seven nursing homes after seven residents died in the aftermath of the storm. These facilities had evacuated to a warehouse in Tangipahoa Parish where conditions were found to be unsanitary and unsafe.

Warner Thomas, President and CEO of Ochsner Health, which operates two hospitals in the hardest-hit parishes, acknowledged the challenges. "Our hospitals are functioning as emergency rooms, but we're not fully operational," Thomas said. "We're doing everything we can to serve our communities during this difficult time."

The Carnival Glory cruise ship, docked in New Orleans, has provided a unique solution for housing first responders and utility workers, offering them a place to rest and recharge. However, many residents continue to struggle with basic necessities like fuel, water, and shelter.

Kim Bass, a resident of St. John the Baptist Parish, described the ongoing challenges: "We're still without power, and the water isn't safe to drink. It's like we're living in a nightmare that won't end."

Michael Lathers, from LaPlace, echoed Bass's sentiments, saying, "It's been a week and a half, and we're still living like this. It's frustrating to see the slow progress."

As of Tuesday, about 3,200 people were in mass shelters, while 25,000 were being housed in FEMA hotel rooms for transitional sheltering. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has approved a total of 159,000 household applications for disaster assistance.

Entergy Louisiana President and CEO Phillip May assured the public that progress is being made, albeit slower than desired. "We're working around the clock, but some areas may not have power until the end of September," May said. "We understand the hardship this is causing, and we're doing everything in our power to restore service as quickly and safely as possible."

The death toll from Ida in Louisiana has risen to 15, with several fatalities attributed to injuries and a lack of oxygen during the power outage. The storm's aftermath has exposed the vulnerability of the state's infrastructure and the need for more resilient systems in the face of increasingly severe weather events.

In the coming days and weeks, Louisiana will continue its long road to recovery, with residents and officials alike hoping for a return to some semblance of normalcy. The state's ability to bounce back from Ida's devastation will be a testament to the resilience of its people and the effectiveness of its disaster response efforts.

Oct 21 (Reuters) – The FBI has confirmed that the remains found in a Florida nature reserve are those of Brian Laundrie, the boyfriend of Gabby Petito, whose disappearance and subsequent murder captivated the nation. Laundrie, who had been missing for over a month, was named a person of interest in Petito's case.

Gabby Petito, a 22-year-old Long Island native, vanished during a cross-country road trip with Laundrie, which they documented on social media. The couple's journey began in Florida and took them through New York before heading westward across the United States. Their adventure turned tragic when Petito's body was discovered in Wyoming's Bridger-Teton National Forest on September 19. The Teton County Coroner later ruled her death a homicide by strangulation, estimating that she had been killed three to four weeks prior to her discovery.

On August 12, a 911 caller reported an altercation between Petito and Laundrie in Moab, Utah. Police intervened and separated the couple for the night, but no charges were filed. Petito was last seen leaving a hotel in Salt Lake City on August 24, and her final communication with her mother occurred on August 25, when she said they were heading to Grand Teton National Park.

Travel bloggers reported seeing what appeared to be the couple's van in the Bridger-Teton National Forest on August 27, raising concerns about Petito's whereabouts. Her family reported her missing on September 11, and Laundrie, who returned to his parents' home in Florida without Petito on September 1, refused to speak with investigators. He was named a person of interest by police on September 15.

Laundrie's disappearance from his parents' home in North Port, Florida, on September 13 added another layer of mystery to the case. An extensive search was conducted in the nearby Carlton Reserve, a vast and rugged wilderness area, where Laundrie's remains were eventually found on October 20. Personal items belonging to Laundrie, including a notebook and a backpack, were discovered alongside the remains, leading to their identification.

The confirmation of Laundrie's death brings an end to the manhunt but leaves many questions unanswered. The cause of Laundrie's death has not been officially disclosed, and no charges were ever filed against him in connection with Petito's murder. The FBI's investigation into the circumstances surrounding Petito's death and Laundrie's actions remains ongoing.

The tragic story of Gabby Petito and Brian Laundrie has drawn international attention, sparking conversations about domestic violence and the way law enforcement responds to missing persons cases, particularly involving young women. The case also highlights the power of social media in mobilizing public interest and support for investigations.

As the investigation continues, the families of both Petito and Laundrie are left to grapple with the loss and the lingering questions surrounding their loved ones' final days. The FBI's findings may provide some closure, but the full story of what transpired during their ill-fated journey may never be fully known.

Taliban Takeover: Chaos, Withdrawal, and the New Afghanistan

Sept 15 (Reuters) – The fall of Kabul on Aug. 15, as Taliban fighters swept through the Afghan capital, marked the end of a two-decade-long U.S.-led military intervention and the beginning of a new, uncertain era for the war-torn country. As the insurgents took control, scenes of chaos unfolded at Kabul's Hamid Karzai International Airport, with desperate Afghans and foreigners clamoring to evacuate.

U.S. President Joe Biden, facing intense global criticism for the withdrawal, defended his decision on Aug. 17. "I stand squarely behind my decision," he said. "After 20 years, I've learned the hard way that there was never a good time to withdraw U.S. forces."

Taliban spokesperson Zabihullah Mujahid sought to reassure the international community in a press conference, promising that "women will have their rights, but within the framework of Islam." He also vowed there would be "no revenge" against those who worked with foreign forces.

Despite these assurances, reports of human rights abuses and violent incidents emerged throughout August, including anti-Taliban protests and a suicide bomb attack near the airport that claimed scores of lives. The United States responded with drone strikes against Islamic State threats, as U.S. General Frank McKenzie, the head of U.S. Central Command, vowed to "continue over-the-horizon capability to strike terrorists."

On Aug. 30, General McKenzie announced the completion of the U.S. troop withdrawal, marking the end of America's longest war. "The last C-17 lifted off from Hamid Karzai International Airport at 3:29 p.m. East Coast time, and the last U.S. soldier left about an hour ago," he said.

In the following days, the Taliban moved to establish a new government, which was announced on Sept. 7. As Kabul airport reopened for aid and domestic flights, international donors pledged $1.1 billion to address the worsening humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan.

However, the world remains wary of the Taliban's promises, with concerns over human rights, particularly women's rights, and the potential for the country to once again become a haven for terrorists. The international community continues to grapple with how to engage with the new regime while ensuring the protection of vulnerable Afghans.

"The world is watching closely," said a Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. "The Taliban's actions will speak louder than their words, and the international community will judge them accordingly."

'Foxitis' and Falsehoods: Capitol Riot Defendant Anthony Antonio Acknowledges Misinformation Role in Insurrection

Washington – Anthony Antonio, a defendant charged with five federal crimes in connection with the January 6 Capitol riot, has admitted that he was driven to participate in the insurrection due to a belief, fueled by misinformation from Fox News and former President Donald Trump, that "America was being robbed of a president." Antonio's lawyer, Joseph Hurley, coined the term 'Foxitis' to describe his client's condition after he lost his job and became immersed in Fox News programming.

In an interview, Antonio expressed regret for his actions, acknowledging that President Joe Biden is the legitimate leader of the United States. "I felt deceived by all the false information about the election," he said. "I know now that what I did was wrong, and I take full responsibility for my actions."

Antonio's case highlights the influence of right-wing media and political rhetoric in the lead-up to the insurrection, as many other defendants have attempted to shift blame onto Trump. However, judges have shown skepticism about these claims, focusing instead on the personal responsibility of those who stormed the Capitol.

During the riot, court documents reveal that Antonio was among the crowd shouting at police, pouring water on an officer, and entering the Capitol building. Reflecting on the events, Antonio expressed remorse for not aiding DC Metropolitan Police Officer Michael Fanone, who was injured during the chaos. "I should have helped him, and I didn't," he said. "That's something I'll have to live with for the rest of my life."

As part of the massive federal inquiry into the insurrection, the Justice Department has already charged hundreds of individuals from 43 states and Washington, DC. Federal prosecutors anticipate charging at least 500 people in connection with the breach of the Capitol, underscoring the scale of the investigation.

Joseph Hurley, Antonio's attorney, emphasized the impact of Fox News on his client's actions, stating, "This is a cautionary tale about the power of misinformation and how it can lead people down a path they never thought they'd be on." He added, "In Anthony's case, 'Foxitis' became a catalyst for his involvement in the Capitol riot."

The insurrection, which left five people dead and caused extensive damage to the Capitol, has raised concerns about the role of media in disseminating false information and the potential for further acts of violence driven by such narratives. As the legal proceedings continue, the cases of defendants like Antonio will serve as a stark reminder of the consequences of believing and acting on misinformation.

Historical Precedent: Impeaching Ex-Officeholders, From William Blount to Donald Trump

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — As the Senate gears up for the impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump, a historical precedent set nearly 230 years ago by U.S. Senator William Blount offers insights into the constitutionality and potential consequences of trying a federal official after they have left office. Blount, a Tennessee statesman, became the first senator to be impeached in 1797, a case that resonates with the current debate surrounding Trump's impeachment.

"Impeachment is a political process, not a criminal one," explained Jonathan Turley, a professor at George Washington University. "It's designed to remove officials from office, but it doesn't necessarily end their political careers."

In 1797, Blount was impeached for his role in a conspiracy to incite a Native American attack on Spanish territories in present-day Florida, with the aim of benefiting Great Britain. The Senate expelled him before the trial could proceed, mirroring discussions about impeaching Trump post-presidency.

Stewart Harris, a constitutional law professor and Blount Mansion board member at Lincoln Memorial University, emphasized the Senate's flexibility in conducting impeachment trials. "The Constitution doesn't specify when the trial must take place," Harris said. "It's up to the Senate to decide, and they chose to proceed with Blount's trial despite his expulsion."

However, Blount's case was ultimately dismissed on jurisdictional grounds, as the Senate determined it lacked the authority to try a former senator. Blount, who did not attend his trial, went on to have a successful political career in Tennessee, serving in the state's legislature and holding other local offices.

Dr. Gregory Ablavsky, a history professor at Stanford University, shed light on the significance of Blount's case. "Impeachment doesn't necessarily spell the end of a political career," Ablavsky said. "Blount's story shows that even after such a scandal, an official can still find support and continue in politics."

Another precedent for post-office impeachment comes from the case of Secretary of War William Belknap, who resigned in 1876 to avoid impeachment but was still impeached and tried by the Senate for bribery. Though he was acquitted, Belknap's case underscores the Senate's authority to proceed with trials regardless of an official's resignation.

HOUSTON, Sept 20 – Royal Dutch Shell, the leading oil producer in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, is grappling with significant damage from Hurricane Ida, which has disrupted its production and is expected to impact output into early 2022. The powerful storm, which made landfall in late August, has removed an estimated 28 million barrels from the market, sending crude prices higher as buyers seek alternatives to the sought-after Gulf Mars grade.

Three weeks after Hurricane Ida, approximately 40% of Shell's offshore production in the region remains offline. The company's crucial transfer facility, West Delta-143, sustained damage that has disrupted the supply of Mars sour crude, a key grade favored by refiners in both the United States and Asia. This disruption has led Rystad Energy analysts to estimate that the Gulf of Mexico's oil supply could be reduced by 200,000 to 250,000 barrels per day (bpd) for several months.

As a result of the supply constraints, Mars crude prices reached a one-year high this month. However, they have since retreated to a $2 per barrel discount to the U.S. benchmark. Shell's Mars and Ursa oilfields, which together contribute around 200,000 bpd, are anticipated to be affected by the storm's aftermath into the first quarter of the new year.

The broader impact of Hurricane Ida on the Gulf's energy sector is also significant, with 18% of the region's oil and 27% of its natural gas production still offline more than three weeks after the storm. Mars crude, a vital component of the U.S. export market, accounted for about 5.5% of total U.S. crude exports in the first eight months of 2021.

The prolonged shutdown of the WD-143 platform is not just affecting Shell but also smaller operators in the area, such as LLOG Exploration Co LLC. This extended disruption underscores the challenge faced by the industry in restoring production and highlights the vulnerability of the Gulf's energy infrastructure to extreme weather events.

Shell has not yet provided a timeline for the full restoration of its operations, but the company is working diligently to repair the damage and resume production as soon as possible. The prolonged outage at the West Delta-143 facility, a critical hub for several Gulf of Mexico oilfields, underscores the complexity of the recovery process and the potential for continued market volatility in the coming months.

In the meantime, refiners and traders are seeking alternative sources of crude, potentially putting upward pressure on prices for other grades. The aftermath of Hurricane Ida serves as a reminder of the interconnectedness of the global oil market and the significant role the Gulf of Mexico plays in supplying energy to both domestic and international markets.

KENOSHA – Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager who shot and killed two people and wounded another during protests in Kenosha last year, was acquitted of all charges by a jury on Friday, sparking a national conversation about self-defense, gun rights, and racial justice.

Rittenhouse, now 18, faced charges including first-degree intentional homicide after the August 2020 shootings during unrest that followed the police shooting of Jacob Blake Jr. The jury, after more than three days of deliberations, supported Rittenhouse's claim that he acted in self-defense.

Corey Chirafisi, one of Rittenhouse's defense attorneys, expressed relief outside the courthouse, saying, "We're thankful to the jury for seeing the truth." Rittenhouse himself broke down in tears as the verdicts were read, later telling reporters, "I'm just glad it's all over."

Thomas Binger, the lead prosecutor, acknowledged the jury's decision but expressed disappointment, stating, "We respect the verdict that the jury has reached." Kenosha County District Attorney Michael Graveley added, "The jury has spoken, and we must respect their decision."

The victims' families reacted with sadness and frustration. Anthony Huber's parents, Karen Bloom and John Huber, said in a statement, "We are heartbroken and angry that justice was not delivered for our Anthony."

President Joe Biden called for calm, saying, "While the verdict in Kenosha will leave many Americans feeling angry and concerned, myself included, we must acknowledge that the jury has spoken." U.S. Senator Ron Johnson, a Wisconsin Republican, said, "I respect the jury's decision and call for peace in Kenosha and across our state."

Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes, a Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate in Wisconsin, criticized the verdict, tweeting, "This system yet again protected someone who shouldn't have been on the street in the first place." Governor Tony Evers echoed the call for peace, urging "Wisconsin to come together, to recognize that we have a long way to go, and to commit ourselves to making our communities safe for everyone."

The case has polarized the country, with some seeing Rittenhouse as a symbol of Second Amendment rights and self-defense, while others view him as a provocateur who should be held accountable for the violence. Mark Richards, another defense attorney, contended that Rittenhouse "had every right to be there" and acted in self-defense against perceived threats.

Prosecutors, however, painted a different picture, arguing that Rittenhouse sought out confrontation. Binger argued during the trial that Rittenhouse "provoked everything that happened that night." The prosecution's efforts to undermine Rittenhouse's self-defense claim were ultimately unsuccessful with the jury.

The acquittal has reignited debates over Wisconsin's self-defense laws and the broader implications for accountability in similar cases. Some advocates argue that the verdict could embolden individuals to take the law into their own hands, while others see it as a reinforcement of the right to protect oneself.

Child Tax Credit: $15 Billion in August Payments to Aid 61 Million Families

BALTIMORE (WBFF/WKRC) – As part of the American Rescue Plan, the expanded federal Child Tax Credit is set to distribute approximately $15 billion in payments to millions of American families this month. These financial boosts will directly benefit roughly 61 million children across the country.

Scheduled for direct deposit on August 15, with mailed checks following shortly thereafter, this month's payment is the second in a series of six monthly installments planned for 2021. Families can expect to receive $300 per child under the age of 6 and $250 per child between the ages of 6 and 17. This initiative aims to provide financial relief to eligible families with at least one child under 18.

The American Rescue Plan, enacted in March, has restructured the Child Tax Credit for this year. Instead of a lump sum during tax season, the first half of the credit is being distributed through these monthly checks. The remaining half will be claimed when families file their taxes in 2022.

To qualify for the full credit, income thresholds have been set at $150,000 for joint filers, $112,500 for heads of households, and $75,000 for single filers. For incomes exceeding these limits, the Child Tax Credit will phase out at a rate of $50 for every $1,000 above the threshold.

In July, about 15% of recipients experienced an issue with their direct deposit, which the IRS has confirmed is being addressed to ensure a smoother distribution for August's payment. It is crucial for recipients to note that the IRS will send a letter at the end of the year to document the total amount received, as this information will be necessary for tax filing in 2022.

These monthly payments are expected to have a significant impact on reducing child poverty and assisting families who have been financially impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. As the August 15th deadline approaches, millions of families eagerly await the continued support from the expanded Child Tax Credit.

OXFORD TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) – A 15-year-old sophomore, Ethan Crumbley, has been charged as an adult with murder and terrorism in connection with the Oxford High School shooting that left four students dead and several others injured in Oxford, Michigan. This marks the deadliest school shooting in the United States since 2018.

Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald said the attack was premeditated, detailing that Crumbley had recorded a video the night before the shooting in which he discussed his plans to kill students. "This was not just an impulsive act," McDonald said during a press conference.

Crumbley faces 24 charges, including four counts of first-degree murder and seven counts of attempted murder. A not guilty plea was entered on his behalf by his defense attorney, Scott Kozak. "We are still in the very beginning stages of this investigation," Kozak said, declining further comment.

The shooting took place just hours after Crumbley's parents met with school officials regarding their son's concerning behavior. According to Sheriff Mike Bouchard, "There was a face-to-face meeting with the suspect and his parents, and at that point, there wasn't enough to even keep him in the office, much less send him home."

Disturbingly, the 9 mm Sig Sauer handgun used in the attack was purchased by Crumbley's father just one week prior, according to Assistant Prosecutor Marc Keast. This has raised questions about the family's responsibility in securing the firearm.

In the aftermath of the tragedy, McDonald has emphasized the need for stricter gun laws and is considering charging Crumbley's parents for their role in the incident. "I am not aware of any other situation where a parent or parents are being charged in connection with their child having access to a weapon used in a school shooting," she said.

The terrorism charge, a rare move in a school shooting case, was chosen to reflect the broader impact on the students, families, and the entire community, McDonald explained. "It was not just an attack on those individuals. It was an attack on that entire community," she added.

As the investigation continues, authorities have urged the public to report any potential threats to law enforcement and cautioned against spreading rumors on social media. "We need to make sure that we're not feeding into the fears of this community," Bouchard said.

The Oxford High School shooting has reignited the national debate on gun control and school safety. In a chilling irony, Jennifer Crumbley, Ethan's mother, had previously written an open letter to then-President Donald Trump in 2018, expressing her support for gun rights and detailing her family's struggles. In the letter, she mentioned making "sacrifices" to ensure her son had access to firearms training.

This latest mass killing, one of 31 in the U.S. this year, has left the Oxford community and the nation grappling with the devastating consequences of gun violence in schools. The trial of Ethan Crumbley will undoubtedly bring further scrutiny to the intersection of mental health, gun ownership, and the responsibilities of parents in preventing such tragedies.

Chris Cuomo Gets COVID-19 Vaccine in Hamptons Amidst Controversy Over Early Testing

The vaccination of Chris Cuomo at a public clinic, rather than through any special arrangement, seems to indicate a move away from the controversies that marred his early pandemic experience. However, the damage to his public image, as well as that of his brother, remains a topic of discussion.

Texas ICU Nurse's Fear: "Lifting Mask Mandate Could Cost More Lives"

CNN – Brittany Smart, an ICU nurse in Texas, is on the brink of exhaustion as she battles the relentless Covid-19 pandemic. With Texas Governor Greg Abbott's recent decision to lift the statewide mask mandate and capacity limits on businesses, Smart's fears for the future have escalated.

"I'm scared," Smart said, her voice filled with concern. "We're not out of the woods yet. Just when we thought we were making progress, this feels like a giant step backward."

Despite the ongoing vaccination campaign and a recent decline in Covid-19 cases, health care workers like Smart are wary of the governor's move. Dr. Rochelle Walensky, Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, echoed these concerns, stating, "We are at a critical plateau where we have seen the steep decline in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths level off at a very high number."

Over the past week, the United States has averaged over 65,000 new Covid-19 cases daily, with Texas reporting more than 6,600 new cases and over 270 deaths in a single day. Currently, more than 5,600 patients are hospitalized in Texas due to the virus.

For Smart, the reality of the pandemic is still grim. "Patients are still dying," she said. "Yes, our hospitals aren't as overcrowded as before, but that doesn't mean the virus has stopped taking lives."

As Texas and other states navigate the delicate balance between economic recovery and public health, the concerns of frontline workers like Brittany Smart serve as a stark reminder that the fight against Covid-19 is far from over.

The Royal Divide: A BBC Docu-Drama Unveils the Tumultuous Path of Harry and Meghan

Stimulus Checks: How $850 Billion Changed American Spending Habits and Shaped the Economy

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the US government has injected over $850 billion into the economy through three rounds of stimulus checks, aimed at supporting households grappling with financial hardships. These payments, collectively known as Economic Impact Payments, have played a significant role in shoring up personal income, consumer spending, and overall economic growth.

When the first stimulus checks were distributed in April 2020, unemployment rates soared, and 75% of recipients used the funds to cover essential household expenses. This lifeline was crucial during a time when millions of Americans lost their jobs or experienced reduced income due to pandemic-related shutdowns.

However, as the pandemic persisted, spending patterns shifted with subsequent stimulus checks. In the second round, recipients allocated their funds differently: 22% for spending, 26% for saving, and a notable 51% for paying off debts. By the third round, these percentages changed further, with only 19% spent, 32% saved, and 49% used for debt repayment.

The stimulus checks were designed to target low- and middle-income households, with a gradual decline in benefits for individuals earning over $75,000. As a result, high-income households were more likely to save or pay off debts with their stimulus funds, contributing to a rise in personal savings across the country.

These payments not only alleviated short-term financial stress but also had lasting effects on consumer spending and the overall economy. The influx of cash allowed many households to maintain their spending levels, which in turn supported businesses and helped prevent a more severe economic downturn.

Despite the positive impact of the stimulus checks, a fourth round of direct payments seems unlikely. President Joe Biden is currently focusing on a new infrastructure package, the American Jobs Plan, which aims to create jobs and invest in the nation's public works rather than providing direct relief to individuals.

Nonetheless, over 80 members of Congress have expressed support for recurring $2,000 monthly checks until the end of the pandemic. This proposal, while gaining some traction among progressive lawmakers, has not garnered significant backing from the broader political spectrum.

As the country continues its recovery, the role of stimulus checks in shaping consumer behavior and economic resilience remains evident. While additional direct payments may not be on the horizon, the impact of the $850 billion already distributed will continue to reverberate through the American economy in the months and years to come.

Facebook Suspends Donald Trump for Two Years, Impacting 2024 Election Landscape

In a landmark decision, Facebook has announced a two-year suspension of former President Donald Trump's accounts due to severe policy violations following the January 6 Capitol riots. The suspension, which began on January 7, will end in 2023, potentially allowing Trump to regain a significant social media platform just in time for the 2024 election cycle.

Facebook's vice president of global affairs and communications, Nick Clegg, explained the decision, stating, "Given the gravity of the circumstances that led to Mr. Trump's suspension, we believe his actions constituted a severe violation of our rules which merit the highest penalty available under the new enforcement protocols." Clegg emphasized that the sanctions aim to prevent future violations and maintain the integrity of the platform.

The initial freezing of Trump's accounts came in response to his support for the Capitol storming, with the possibility of permanent removal if further violations occurred. The White House, through press secretary Jennifer Psaki, expressed skepticism about any change in the former president's behavior. "We have long known that President Trump has a history of using social media to spread misinformation and incite violence," Psaki said.

Facebook's decision carries significant implications for Trump's political fundraising efforts, potentially limiting his ability to support Republican candidates in the 2022 midterm elections. Historically, social media platforms have played a crucial role in Trump's fundraising and communication strategies.

In a policy shift, Facebook declared that political figures will no longer receive special treatment and may face suspension if they incite violence. Clegg noted, "Our policies apply to everyone, regardless of their status or role, and will be enforced consistently and transparently."

The decision has drawn criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. Some Democrats argue that the suspension should have been permanent, while Republicans contend that the move infringes on free speech. Bret Jacobson, president of Red Edge, a conservative digital strategy firm, criticized Facebook, saying, "This decision underscores the power that Big Tech wields over political discourse. Whether you agree with Trump or not, the fact that a handful of Silicon Valley executives can silence a former president is deeply troubling."

Facebook's Oversight Board, an independent body tasked with reviewing the platform's content decisions, played a role in the process but did not directly dictate the two-year suspension. The board had previously ordered Facebook to review its initial indefinite suspension, leading to the newly announced time frame.

In the coming years, the fate of Trump's Facebook accounts will depend on assessments of public safety risks. Clegg said, "If we determine that there is still a serious risk to public safety, we will extend the restriction for a set period of time and continue to re-evaluate until that risk has receded."

Third $1,400 Stimulus Checks Set to Roll Out as Part of $1.9 Trillion Covid Relief Package

Washington CNN – A third round of stimulus checks, worth up to $1,400 per person, is on the horizon as part of President Joe Biden's sweeping $1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief package. The bill, which has been approved by the Senate, is expected to clear a final House vote and land on the President's desk for signature. White House press secretary Jen Psaki confirmed the administration's commitment to expediting the distribution of these payments.

"President Biden is eager to get this relief to American families as quickly as possible," Psaki said during a press briefing. "Our team is working around the clock to ensure that these direct payments reach those who need them most."

The relief package is designed to provide financial support to millions of Americans still reeling from the economic impact of the pandemic. Approximately 90% of households will be eligible for the payments, with individuals earning less than $75,000 and couples filing jointly making under $150,000 receiving the full amount. However, the checks will phase out for higher incomes, with individuals earning over $80,000, heads of households making over $120,000, and couples exceeding $160,000 not qualifying for the stimulus.

Eligibility for the payments will be determined based on either the 2019 or 2020 tax returns, depending on which is the most recent. This means that taxpayers whose financial situation worsened in 2020 may still receive a payment if their 2019 income was below the threshold, provided they file their 2020 tax return promptly.

"Taxpayers should file their returns as soon as possible if they believe their 2020 income would make them eligible for a larger stimulus payment," advised Psaki. "We want to ensure that everyone who is entitled to relief gets it."

Despite the urgency to distribute the funds, the ongoing tax filing season may cause a slight delay in the payment process. However, once the bill is enacted, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is expected to start sending out the checks promptly.

Notably, the eligibility criteria for this round of stimulus payments are stricter than in previous rounds, potentially leaving out some higher-income earners who qualified for earlier checks. This shift reflects the Biden administration's focus on targeting relief to those most in need.

MADISON, Wis. (AP) – Judge Bruce Schroeder dismissed a key charge against Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager acquitted of killing two men during a protest in Kenosha, Wisconsin, ruling that the AR-15-style rifle he used did not meet the definition of a short-barreled weapon, which is illegal for minors to possess in the state.

The dismissal of the gun possession charge, a misdemeanor, came as Rittenhouse, now 18, faced five felony charges, including murder, for which he was ultimately found not guilty. The judge's decision on the gun charge underscored the complexities surrounding Wisconsin's laws on minors possessing firearms.

Schroeder, explaining his decision, said, "The weapon in question is not a short-barreled rifle, and therefore, the defendant cannot be convicted of this offense."

Rittenhouse's defense team, led by attorneys Mark Richards and Corey Chirafisi, argued that their client was protected by a legal exception that allows minors to possess shotguns and rifles if they are not short-barreled. Chirafisi contended, "The law is clear. He's allowed to have that weapon."

Assistant District Attorney James Kraus opposed the dismissal, contending that Rittenhouse's actions went beyond what the law intended. "The spirit of the law was not for 17-year-olds to be out on the streets with these weapons," Kraus said.

Legal experts like Michael Cicchini, a defense attorney, noted the ambiguity in the law and its potential for interpretation. "When the law is unclear, you have to construe it in favor of the defendant to prevent the government from abusing its power," Cicchini explained.

Wisconsin's law on minors possessing firearms has evolved over time, with legislative changes that have expanded and refined prohibitions and exceptions. The exception allowing minors to possess long guns for hunting purposes may have been influenced by efforts to promote a culture of lifetime gun ownership.

Jeri Bonavia, executive director of the Wisconsin Anti-Violence Effort, criticized the law's ambiguity, stating, "No one could have foreseen that this exception would be used in a situation like Kenosha, where a teenager brought a military-style weapon to a protest."

Tom Grieve, a Milwaukee attorney and former prosecutor, observed that the debate over the exception's intention raises questions about the broader implications of the law. "Was it meant solely for hunting, or did it inadvertently open the door for situations like this?" Grieve asked.

State Senator Jon Erpenbach, a Democrat, echoed concerns about the law's unintended consequences. "We need to have a serious conversation about these types of weapons and who should be allowed to possess them, especially in public spaces," he said.

The Rittenhouse case has sparked a national debate on gun rights, self-defense, and the role of minors in contentious public situations. As Wisconsin and other states grapple with the complexities of their firearms legislation, the case serves as a reminder of the need for clear and concise laws that can withstand the test of time and changing social contexts.

Facebook Whistleblower Frances Haugen Calls for Mark Zuckerberg's Resignation Over Safety Concerns

Frances Haugen, the former Facebook employee turned whistleblower, has publicly called for Mark Zuckerberg to step down as CEO of Meta, the parent company of Facebook, arguing that his focus on the metaverse project is diverting attention from crucial issues of user safety and misinformation. Haugen, who leaked thousands of internal documents revealing the company's internal struggles, claims that a change in leadership is necessary to prioritize the well-being of the platform's users.

"Mark Zuckerberg has so much control over Meta through his majority ownership of voting shares, which makes it nearly impossible for shareholders to hold him accountable," Haugen said. "A new leader, one who prioritizes safety over expansion, could strengthen Facebook and rebuild trust with its users."

Meta, which recently rebranded itself to signal its focus on the metaverse, has faced intense scrutiny over its handling of user data, misinformation, and its impact on mental health. Haugen's leaked documents exposed that Instagram, a subsidiary of Facebook, can have a detrimental effect on teenagers' mental health, as well as the company's role in spreading misinformation and exacerbating ethnic violence in some countries.

"The choice to prioritize growth over safety is unconscionable," Haugen testified before the US Congress and UK Parliament, advocating for external regulation of tech companies. "It's time for Meta to be held accountable by an independent oversight board, not just by its own leadership."

In response to Haugen's claims, a Meta spokesperson defended the company's efforts, stating, "We've invested more than $13 billion in safety and security since 2016, and we continue to make significant investments to keep our community safe. It's possible to both build new technologies like the metaverse and work on addressing important issues."

Haugen's revelations have sparked a global conversation about the responsibilities of tech giants and the need for regulatory oversight. Critics argue that Meta's focus on the metaverse, a virtual reality space where users can interact in a 3D environment, distracts from the pressing issues that still plague its existing platforms.

The leaked documents, known as the Facebook Papers, have painted a picture of a company struggling to manage the consequences of its own success. They reveal internal debates about the amplification of harmful content, the challenges of moderating content in non-English languages, and the company's struggle to curb misinformation, particularly around the 2020 US presidential election and the COVID-19 pandemic.

French Health Authority Recommends Against Moderna Vaccine for Under 30s Over Myocarditis Risk

France's Haute Autorite de Sante (HAS) has advised against the use of Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine, Spikevax, for individuals under the age of 30 due to a heightened risk of myocarditis, a rare inflammatory heart condition. The recommendation, based on recent data and a French study published on Monday, suggests that the risk of myocarditis is five times lower with Pfizer's Comirnaty jab in this age group.

Despite the European Union's drug regulator, the European Medicines Agency (EMA), approving Moderna's booster vaccine for all adults aged 18 and over, the HAS's decision underscores concerns about the potential side effects in younger populations. The EMA has acknowledged a possible link between myocarditis and pericarditis, another inflammatory heart condition, with both Moderna's and Pfizer-BioNTech's mRNA vaccines. However, the EMA maintains that the benefits of these vaccines in preventing COVID-19 significantly outweigh the risks.

HAS's guidance applies not only to the first and second doses but also to the third 'booster' dose for individuals under 30. For those aged 30 and above, the authority recommends the Moderna vaccine, citing its slightly higher effectiveness compared to Pfizer's offering. The decision will remain in effect until further scientific data on the matter becomes available.

This recommendation aligns with the cautious approach taken by U.S. regulators and the World Health Organization (WHO), both of which have echoed the EMA's stance on the overall benefits of mRNA vaccines. While acknowledging the potential risks, these global health bodies continue to endorse the use of Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines as crucial tools in the fight against the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

WASHINGTON (AP) – The Defense Department imposed unusual restrictions on the National Guard during the Capitol riot on January 6, leading to a delay in sending assistance as the building was breached by supporters of then-President Donald Trump, according to Maj. Gen. William Walker, the Commanding General of the District of Columbia National Guard.

In Senate hearings, Walker revealed that he received a request for help from the Capitol Police at 1:49 p.m. but did not receive approval from the Defense Department until 5:08 p.m., resulting in a critical delay in the Guard's arrival at the scene. "I was stunned. There was a sense of urgency," Walker testified.

Pentagon officials were reportedly concerned about the image of a large National Guard presence at the Capitol, fearing it could be perceived as militarizing the event. Robert Salesses, a senior Pentagon official, defended the decision, stating, "There was a concern about the optics of having a large military presence at the Capitol."

The Capitol riot exposed significant security lapses and a lack of preparation by law enforcement agencies. The FBI faced scrutiny for not adequately sharing intelligence that warned of potential violence. Jill Sanborn, the Bureau's top counterterrorism official, acknowledged, "We fell short, and I take responsibility for that."

The Metropolitan Police Department, under the leadership of Acting Chief Robert Contee, also faced challenges due to the delay in National Guard assistance. Contee criticized the communication breakdown, saying, "There was a clear breakdown in the chain of command."

Sen. Roy Blunt, a Republican from Missouri, highlighted the controversy surrounding the exact timeline and approval process for the National Guard's deployment. "It's still not clear to me why it took so long for the National Guard to be deployed," he said during the hearings.

As congressional investigations delve into the security failures on January 6, officials are pointing fingers over who is responsible. The Capitol Police were aware of a possible plot by a militia group to breach the Capitol again, raising questions about their preparedness. This disruption to network traffic had a cascading effect on the way our data centers communicate, bringing our services to a halt."

Janardhan further clarified that an engineer issued a command that unintentionally severed Facebook's global data center connections. The company's audit tool, designed to prevent such errors, failed to block the faulty command. As a result, Facebook was removed from the Domain Name System (DNS) servers, complicating efforts to investigate and resolve the issue.

The Department of Defense was contacted for comment, but the claim of a military raid has been rated as false based on the information provided by Facebook and the lack of any supporting evidence from official sources.

The company cited concerns that the content was contributing to the ongoing unrest in the United States. In a statement, YouTube said it had "removed new content uploaded to the Donald J. Trump channel for violating our policies. It now has its first strike & is temporarily prevented from uploading new content for a minimum of seven days."

Facebook and Twitter took unprecedented steps last week, indefinitely suspending Trump's accounts after they determined that his posts posed a risk of incitement to violence. The storming of the Capitol on January 6th, which left five people dead, was fueled in part by rhetoric from the President and his supporters.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton has responded to these suspensions by issuing legal demands, or civil investigative demands, to major tech companies, including Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Apple, over their decisions to ban Trump and the conservative social media platform Parler. Paxton alleges that the companies may have engaged in "anticompetitive, suppressive, and/or discriminatory practices."

Criticism has emerged against YouTube for not taking stronger action against Trump's account earlier, with some arguing that the platform should have been more vigilant in enforcing its policies against misinformation and incitement. Unlike Twitter and Facebook, YouTube operates a three-strike system for taking down channels. A first strike results in a one-week upload ban, a second strike leads to a two-week suspension, and a third strike can lead to the permanent removal of the channel.

Social media companies have faced intense scrutiny for their handling of misinformation and inciteful content, particularly in the lead-up to the 2020 U.S. presidential election and in its aftermath. In the wake of the Capitol attack, many tech companies have taken steps to limit the spread of harmful content. Google, for instance, has paused political ads across its platforms, a move aimed at preventing the exploitation of its services ahead of President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20th.

The suspension of Trump's accounts on YouTube, Facebook, and Twitter significantly curtails his ability to communicate with his millions of followers via major social media platforms. This comes at a time when tensions between the President and tech companies are escalating, with questions being raised about the power and responsibility of these companies in regulating online speech.

The Ever Given Incident: A Wake-Up Call for Global Shipping and Supply Chain Resilience

Capt. Hanse Kurisinkal, the leader of the retrieval crew that took over the Ever Given after it was dislodged, recounts the harrowing experience: "It was a testament to the skill and determination of the team that we were able to free the vessel, but it was a stark reminder of how one incident can disrupt the entire world's commerce."

The Ever Given, after undergoing repairs in a Chinese port, is set to resume its sailing duties, underscoring the importance of maintenance in ensuring the smooth flow of goods across the globe. However, the incident had far-reaching consequences, with some perishable goods onboard being auctioned or discarded due to a contingency situation declared by the ship's owner, necessitating customers to pay fees to retrieve their cargo.

Maritime analyst Cormac Mc Garry of Control Risks weighs in on the broader implications, stating, "This incident serves as a wake-up call for the industry. The concentration of such large volumes of cargo in a single vessel increases the risk to global supply chains. If a similar event were to occur in a conflict zone, the consequences could be catastrophic."

The ship's journey to China for repairs emphasized the high costs associated with managing damage to these colossal vessels. With costs running into millions of dollars, the incident raises questions about the financial resilience of ship owners in the face of potential disasters.

An unnamed officer involved in the operation highlighted the unique challenges of navigating these mammoth ships, particularly in adverse weather conditions: "The sheer size of these vessels means they are more susceptible to wind resistance, making them difficult to control. This incident underscores the need for better training, technology, and contingency planning."

The Ever Given's predicament also brought to light the plight of stranded crews, who often face uncertain futures in cases of ship abandonment. The incident serves as a reminder of the human dimension of the global shipping industry and the need for better protections for seafarers.

Cormac Mc Garry adds, "The well-being of the crew is often overlooked, but they are the backbone of this industry. We need to ensure that their rights and working conditions are protected, especially in times of crisis."

Moving forward, the maritime industry and global supply chain stakeholders must grapple with the lessons learned from the Ever Given's misfortune. This includes improving communication, contingency planning, and investing in technology to mitigate the risks associated with these ultra-large container vessels.

As Capt. Kurisinkal aptly puts it, "The Ever Given incident is a catalyst for change. It's time to reassess our reliance on these giants of the sea and work towards a more resilient, diversified, and sustainable shipping network."

CNN – Washington, DC

In a historic and unprecedented move, the House of Representatives voted to impeach President Donald Trump for a second time, making this the most bipartisan impeachment in US history. Ten Republican representatives broke ranks to join Democrats in the 232-197 vote, a stark contrast to the party-line divisions seen in previous impeachments.

The decision to impeach Trump comes just one week after a mob of his supporters stormed the US Capitol, leaving five people dead and causing extensive damage. The article of impeachment accuses the President of "incitement of insurrection," charging him with encouraging the violent attack on Congress as it was certifying President-elect Joe Biden's electoral victory.

Among the Republicans who voted for impeachment are Rep. Liz Cheney, the third-ranking House Republican, and Rep. Tom Rice, both of whom are not typically considered moderates within their party. This level of cross-party support is highly unusual, as previous impeachments – Andrew Johnson in 1868, Bill Clinton in 1998, and Trump's first impeachment in 2019 – saw near-uniform party-line voting.

Trump's job approval rating among Republicans, while still high at over 70%, has seen a decline in the wake of the Capitol siege. Two of the Republicans who voted for impeachment, Reps. Dan Newhouse and Jamie Herrera Beutler, represent districts in Washington state, a region known for its non-partisan top-two primary system, which may have influenced their decision.

The only historical parallel to this level of bipartisan support for impeachment is the attempt against President Richard Nixon in 1974, when a growing number of Republicans began to distance themselves from the embattled president in the face of the Watergate scandal. However, Nixon resigned before the House could vote on articles of impeachment.

Notably, no Democrats voted against impeaching Trump, reflecting a remarkable level of unity within the party. This contrasts with the first impeachment vote, during which a small number of Democrats voted against the proceedings.

The road ahead is uncertain, as the impeachment now moves to the Senate, where a trial will be held to determine Trump's guilt. With less than two weeks left in his term, the timing of the trial could be influenced by the incoming Biden administration's priorities and the Senate's schedule. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has not yet indicated when he will reconvene the Senate for the trial.

CNN – Minneapolis, Minnesota

Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis Police officer who was captured on video kneeling on George Floyd's neck for more than nine minutes, was found guilty Tuesday of second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter. The verdict, which followed weeks of intense testimony and global attention, brings a measure of justice to a case that sparked widespread protests against racial injustice and police brutality.

The jury, consisting of 12 people—5 men and 7 women, with a diverse racial makeup of six White, four Black, and two multiracial jurors—deliberated for approximately 10 hours over two days before reaching their decision. Two alternate jurors, both White women, were dismissed before deliberations began.

The jury selection process, which took place at the Hennepin County Government Center from March 9 to March 23, was meticulous, with both the defense and prosecution using peremptory challenges to shape the panel based on potential jurors' views on policing and the Black Lives Matter movement. Attorneys sought to identify individuals who could remain impartial in a case that had already stirred deep emotions across the country.

George Floyd's death on May 25, 2020, became a rallying cry for social justice, as bystander video showed Chauvin kneeling on Floyd's neck for 9 minutes and 29 seconds, while Floyd repeatedly said, "I can't breathe." The incident led to global protests and a renewed push for police reform.

Chauvin now faces a maximum sentence of 40 years for second-degree murder, 25 years for third-degree murder, and 10 years for second-degree manslaughter. The actual sentence will be determined by Judge Peter Cahill, who set a tentative date for the sentencing hearing eight weeks from the trial's conclusion.

Throughout the trial, which lasted approximately three weeks, the prosecution called 45 witnesses, including medical experts, police officers, and bystanders. They argued that Chauvin's actions were a direct cause of Floyd's death, while the defense contended that Floyd's underlying health conditions and drug use were responsible.

Three other former Minneapolis Police officers, Tou Thao, J. Alexander Kueng, and Thomas Lane, are charged with aiding and abetting in Floyd's death and are expected to stand trial later this year. The outcome of Chauvin's trial is likely to set a precedent for their cases.

The guilty verdict has brought a sense of relief and vindication to many who have been advocating for justice in the wake of Floyd's death. However, it also serves as a reminder of the ongoing fight against systemic racism and police violence in the United States.

LONDON, Aug 26 – The United Kingdom has received "very, very credible" intelligence of an imminent Islamic State (IS) attack on Kabul airport, prompting the British foreign ministry to advise against all travel to the area, Armed Forces Minister James Heappey said on Thursday.

Heappey warned that the threat of a suicide bomb attack by IS militants was "credible, imminent, and lethal," raising concerns over the safety of those gathered at the airport. "We know that the threat is credible, we know that the threat is imminent, and we know that the threat is likely to be a suicide bomb attack," he told the BBC.

The foreign ministry issued a statement urging British nationals and Afghans who have been assisted by the UK to avoid traveling to the airport and to remain where they are until they receive further instructions. "The security situation in Kabul remains volatile, and the threat from terrorist groups is high," the statement read.

Heappey acknowledged the complexity of the situation, with large crowds still thronging the airport despite the dire warnings. "The challenge is that there are still thousands of people at the Abbey Gate, at the Baron Hotel, and in the areas around the airport," he said. "It is an incredibly dangerous situation, and we are doing everything we can to get people out as quickly and as safely as possible."

The Western nations, including the UK, have been relying on the Taliban for security outside the airport, a situation that has raised eyebrows given the extremist group's history of violence. However, the focus remains on evacuation efforts, with the UK having successfully evacuated over 12,000 people since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan.

Heappey confirmed that the UK plans to operate 11 more evacuation flights, but the deteriorating security situation casts doubt on whether all eligible individuals will be able to leave. Approximately 400 people, mostly British or dual nationals, still remain in Afghanistan, and Heappey admitted that not all may be evacuated. "We are working around the clock to get as many people out as we can, but we can't guarantee that everyone will get out," he said.

The race against time to evacuate vulnerable Afghans and foreign nationals comes as the United States, which leads the international effort, has set an August 31 deadline for completing the withdrawal of its troops. The looming threat of an IS attack adds a new layer of urgency and complexity to the already challenging evacuation operation.
